content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Door KickersI picked up Door Kickers during the summer sale, planning on spending some time in it while I was stuck using a laptop out of state. I was pleasantly surprised in many ways, and while this title does have a few setbacks it is a fairly fun indie title that I can't help but praise.GraphicsDoor Kickers is a top-down 2D tactics game, meaning I will critique it less for level of detail and more for art-style and consistency. The official content is appealing to look at, though a SWAT team wearing tan uniforms is an odd sight. Community-created content varies, but in general the game looks fairly decent. My primary complaint is that textures will become blurry as you zoom in. You'll also notice that the enemies you face will regularly use the same sprites, and that levels reuse quite a few assets between each-other.


Kicking Doors and Taking Names 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: Lavernius Regalis




AudioThis game features fairly decent audio design, but my main complaint is how repetitive the ambient sounds are. You'll start hearing the same voices on TVs and radios, and the same shouts emanating from mooks before they are helplessly gunned down by your troops. Eventually, you'll find yourself repeating the TV announcers in your head, staying a second ahead of their words. I will complement game for its soundtrack, though; it works well, is pleasant to listen to, and suits the style/setting of Door Kickers.PerformanceThis game performs very well on virtually any system, due to its 2D sprite-based nature. No issues there, as I would've hoped.GameplayDoor Kickers revolves around planning out an entry route for a SWAT team in various situations, where your primary goal is typically to eliminate all hostiles and possibly defuse a bomb in the process. It is fast-paced, unforgiving, and fun to play. However, there are a few faults with it. The unlock system prevents you from accessing very interesting content such as the Stealth class until after you've spent multiple hours in-game, and the planning system seems to be developed with touchscreens in mind, which makes the process of modifying orders that have already been created very difficult at best. Despite this, I still found that it was fun enough to last for quite a few hours, and I still haven't finished even a third of the game's content.


Aircraft Entry 101 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: Lavernius Regalis




Community ContentDoor Kickers does well in this regard, featuring a built-in mod menu and map/mission editor. It doesn't allow for extensive feature modification, but new weapons, armor, maps, and enemies can be created with ease, and existing ones can be modified to your heart's content. I definitely approve of the game's position here.VerdictDoor Kickers is a very fun indie title to waste some time on, thanks to its light weight, fast-paced yet tactical gameplay which is sure to appeal to fans of Rainbow Six or Ghost Recon. However, I don't believe its production value is quite high enough to justify a purchase at full price. It's definitely fun, but it isn't quite $19.99 wholesale fun. I will be keeping my eye on the development of its sequel, 'Door Kickers 2 - Task Force North', however, as that title looks like it will have considerably higher production value and quality.I would recommend Door Kickers, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

								This is one of the best games ever. I'm not kidding. I have quite a few games; all Battlefields, CS:GO, Rust, DayZ, numerous race games, all Hitmans, but I prefer this game. Why?Well, I love this game, you can play it anytime, any duration that you like. Spend fifteen minutes on a plan, or just rush in and control all the troopers in real-time. I prefer a combination, planning a bit ahead and then work further in real-time.Cons:- I like the police versus criminals idea- I like the old-fashion top-down view- I like that you (new feature!) can throw grenades and flashbangs around corners- I like the ballistic shields and different weapons- I like the different roles (shotgun, rifle, pistol, etc.)What should improve:Nothing in general, it's a good game. Okay, the AI could use some more unpredictability.Summary: I love this game! :D

												I'm not one to write many reviews nor do I often play tactics based games like this.  The fact that I am writing a positive review for this game refelects how enjoyable I have found it.  I love the level challenges and find that the difficulty is set just right.  My biggest disappointment is that a very well thought out run can be won or lost by the random location of enemies and/or the enemies' marksmanship.  Sometimes you can blitz through a level with impressive results but re-run a level you only needed a minor tweak to, in order to improve your time, can result in you looping thorugh the exact same plan 30 times before it works again.There are so many areas to work with and a varied set of levels, plus the ability to make your own or import others, that it keeps you playing.  The RPG like development of team members also adds a good dimension to the gameplay, especially if you play through all the levels with a single squad memberOverall I'd give this game 8 out of 10, the effect of randomising the enemies being the main issue.  I don't expect it to be exactly the same every time but it needs to reduce the luck factor.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door Kickers is an Action/Strategy game which puts you in command of a S.W.A.T. team. you must use planning and tactics to complete the objective (such as rescuing hostages or defusing a bomb) and keep your squad alive.The game is played from a top-down perspective and nearly all of the missions revolve around storming a building. there is a variety of weapons and gadgets to aid you in completing the objective. ( such as spy camera's to look under doors, or flashbangs to temporarily blind enemies) With the introduction of BETA. you can now customise the appearance of the member of your squad. as well as change their names and callsigns.The game also includes a sort of skill tree which allows you to grant extra skills to your squad using points earned by completing levels. there is a variety of skills and more will be implemented as the game develops. (My favourite skill is the one that allows stealth members to hold fire until ordered to shoot)The game also includes different types of S.W.A.T. members. like shotgunners. assualters. stealth ETC. each mission is different and requires careful planning and certain classes will be more efffective than others.finally the game features steam workshop integration. making it possible to create and download user created maps, weapons, gadgets and more!In conclusion. this is a game that is definately worth buying. if you like strategy games. You will like this. The game is currently in BETA and will be updated to include more gear and a campaign mode. i definately recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
 Door Kickers! It's a late night, I ned sleep, but instead I'm writing reviews.  Why? Anyway, I'll make it a moderate sized review I guess, TL;DR at the bottom. Instead of going over every detail like other reviews, I'll go over the little  nooks and crannies only , and not in any order, so let's get to it!  I have a lot more hours on Door Kickers than it seems, I've played the iPad version a lot and lots of offline hours. Progession This game is pretty nice on progression to be honest. You have one class (I'll go over the classes in a second} and as your squad "levels" up, you obtain new classes,  until you get all 5 of them. There are also  stars , which you get for completing certain challenges, such as playing the mission using a single plan, or playing without ever pausing in real-life. With stars, you can buy  new weapons, armor and pretty much everything else . Every time your squad levels up, you get  doctorine points . These can be used to teach our squad special tactics, making them more effective.  Replayablity This game has a  nice freaking sheet  ton of replayablity. The AI makes  different decisions  and spawn in different preset spots (so they  can and will  repeat). There are a ridiculous amount of ways to complete each mission, be it with continuous sync throughout, splitting up to speed it up, or just trying out the best weapons for every situation!  Let's not forget that there's a  ♥♥♥♥ing mission generator  that ♥♥♥♥♥ out missions for you to play that feel like a normal one! Also the steam workshop is utilized pretty well so you can find lots of maps made by people using the level editor. Music   Meh.  The music is alright, but then it just starts turning into some dubstep crap, but if you're fine with a 60 seconds of dubstep or just love it in general, then you'll like it. Gamemodes (WIP)These are the gamemodes you'll play  Clear Hostiles Hostage Rescue Stop Execution Bomb DefusalArrest WarrentDope RaidsRobbery In Progress Some of the above, on a ship or plane or something really cool like that. WIP YEs, I'm tired, I'd appreciate a like or two pretty please though! I'll work on it very soon!

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												An excellent tactical top down simulation of SWAT raids.Pro's:- varied tactical options- Extensive planning options that are remiscent of the Rainbow Six prescenario phase.- RPG element allowing SWAT members to level + there is an overall specialization tree for your team.- A wide variety of weapons and equipment: firearms, explosives, gadgets and more.- a series of nice campaigns- a variety of portraits, options to rename and give callsigns.- diverse and fun scenarios- combat, hostage evacuation, retrieving evidence,... all passes the revue.- easy moddability and already a nice amount of quality content out there.Negatives:- Visuals could've been better.- More portraits would've been nice.- Some sort of good/decent co-op mode would've been fun and interesting.- An option to be the opposing player in specific and difficult scenarios would have been interesting.Global judgement:A must have for fans of tactical combat, extensive planning, tactical puzzles and 'SWAT'.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												In Door Kickers, you take control of a SWAT team in a variety of different hostile situations. It is a top down, 2D realtime strategy game that allows you to make critical decisions at a moment's notice or plan entire missions from the very beginning of an operation. After a few hours of playing the Single Missions, I fell in love with Door Kickers. The controls are simple and easy to understand, and watching your plans in action is always satisfying. The sheer amount of different scenarios, ranging from hostage situations to raiding criminal headquarters, makes each mission feel like a new tactical challenge for your SWAT team. With 6 campaigns, 70+ Official Single Missons, Level Generator, unlockable gear, and downloadable mods, Door Kickers has plenty of content to keep you busy.Although I enjoyed Door Kickers, there are a few minor flaws. The game offers you dozens of unlockable gear such as guns and equipment, but I found myself using what I was comfortable with and had no trouble throughout the game. My only incentive to unlock and test all the guns was for the achievement. Also, there were a few situations in the Single Missions and Campaign that feel unbalanced and in favor of the AI.Overall, Door Kickers was an addicting and enjoyable strategy game from start to finish.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Great tactical game. Takes a bit to get used to the UI but it works well once learned, it's not a standard rip-off of the Starcraft of C&C interface and this is why people might have a bit of a learning curve before you can get into the gameplay. It only took my an hour to get almost everything memorized, not that bad. This game has random maps, pre-made single maps and campaigns. Going through the single maps alone would take a long long time. Campaigns can take a while especially if you have to restart some particularly overly hard missions. Once you play all those most games would be done and become boring, right? Luckily there is a random map generator. You can set size and enemy parameters, and since you don't know exactly what you are going to run in to it ends up being fun for long periods. Even if I have 5 minutes I can run one or two random killhouse maps. Or if I want to spend 3 hours playing a tactical game I can and it still doesn't get dull.Tactically there are various ways to overcome each scenario. You can lockpick a locked door or break it down, or you can use special tools to lockpick it faster or break it faster but these tools take up an inventory slot and are heavier. Or you could use a breacher with a shotgun, but that shotgun becomes the primary weapon and is only useful at short range. There is a give and take to each option and all are viable pending your playstyle and how you want to approach that whole level. And this is just locked doors. The constant variation in the maps and multiple ways to approach each type of situation keeps it varied. Some maps you cannot flank the armored guy and have to face him head on, if you do not have the right equipment you will likely suffer. Sometimes there are too many rooms to flashbang each one so you have to adapt to opening doors and clearing rooms in a different way sweeping around the corner from a wider angle. The game doesn't feel dull even after a long time playing. Gameplay is top-notch and the devs plan on adding to it with co-op and multiplayer eventually. This game has longevity, it hasn't gotten dull yet and I have plenty of hours in it already. It can be played in short spurts or long sessions without an issue. It's a tactical game that requires some thinking. Controls are more than functional and become natural to use with a little bit of time in the game to do exactly what you want down to smaller details like how you want to walk around a corner with a sweeping curve instead of walking straight in. There are various classes that all play differently and can change your play style immensely from one map to another depending on team loadout. You can respec your doctrine points aka skills and you can change classes freely any time you want. I have nothing but good things to say about this game so yes I recommend it. It has been on sale a few times but even full price this is a good one to pick up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This is an incredibly addictive strategy game whereby you command a team of SWAT officers in raids on various compounds.  This game boasts a fairly hefty list of single missions, and a number of multi-layered campaigns.  The briefings are simple, with no overblown storyline - just the basic facts of how many Tangos, and what your objectives are.  How you go about assaulting the compounds is essentially up to you.The player generally gets to command a team of 2-8 officers that, as you progress grow in skill.  The more you play, the more unlocks become available, allowing even more playing styles through different classes (Pointman, Assaulter, Breacher, Stealth, and Shield).Insertion points are fixed, but there are generally some options as to where your team will start from, and who you include on the assault.The game provides an interesting playing experience with it being almost turn-based - but not.  The player has the ability to pause the game and command their officers in where to move, where to look, and basic actions.  This can be done in real time, but more success is had by trusting in your officers AI.  At any point, if you feel your orders aren't working, you can freeze time and change your commands, allowing you to command (somewhat) on the fly.I picked this game up on sale earlier today and have spent around 6 hours playing - so the value for money is high.This is a great game for short stints - allowing you to log in and make an attempt or two at a difficult target, without too much commitment out of your day.  Or, you can just spend hours grinding your way through the various levels.The game is very much like chess, where you need to think a few moves ahead.Basic knowledge of MOUT/urban warfare can help, but trial and error can eventually be as effective.  Just remember to check those corners!The AI Tangos are quality, with numerous classes to go up against.  Just don't be upset if a hostage taker decides to kill their comodoty before they turn the gun on you.The UI isn't perfect and I still fumble with issuing breaching commands on a 'go command', but remember the 7 P's and you'll do alright:  'Proper Planning and Preparation Prevents♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor Performance'.4/5

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								With a loud 'crump' the door turned from 50 year old hardwood, into matchsticks in the blink of an eye. In one fluid motion two armed men stormed through the breach, in a coordinated strike, with all the precision of years of training they checked the room for hostiles. "CLEAR!" the first officer shouted, echoed a moment later by his partner, following in behind them two more armed police moved into the room, leap frogging their comrades positions to take up covering overwatches.Stacking up either side of the next door, one officer leaned forwards, ready to open the door, the second officer priming a flashbang, pin pulled he looked to his colleague and nodded. Turning the handle and throwing the door open the first officer stood back, raising his sleek compact submachine gun, the second tossing the live grenade into the room, an ear splitting bang, and a blinding flash stunning the hostage taker inside, the officers moved in with lethal grace, one three round burst of fire and the aggressor was down, the second officer kneeling to cheek the hostage was unarmed.Door Kickers is a tense top down tactical simulation game, you control a squad of specialist counter-terrorism/hostage rescue officers. You unlock equipment (and soon traits) with stars awarded for completing the levels with no casualties and under the time limit. The interface is clean and easy to use, the controls slick and intuitive, it takes moments to learn but knowing how to control your team is only the start of it.Learning the best combinations of weapons and tactics will prove harder, the game is unforgiving, but in a good way, when you've made a mistake you'll know it, forget to check a corner? You'll pay for it when the 'empty room' turns out to be hiding a hostile with a Mac-10.The game has just recently entered into Beta stage, and it's well worth the money, bugs are few and far between and it runs well and looks great.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you remember Rainbow Six's famous planning phase? Did you enjoy that part of the game more than the actual mission? If you answered yes to these questions, Door Kickers is a worthwhile investment.The game's core features right now are quite good. There is a slight learning curve to get your guys moving the way you want. Sometimes you will feel like you are micromangaging movements especially if you want to execute proper room clearing techniques. And occasionally you get angry at the pathing system since there are numerous house plants and chairs which create impassable barriers. But it is still fun. There are definitely a good number of missions available of varying difficulty. Some you will breeze right through, others will be the bain of your existence until you get that perfect plan with 0 casualties working just right. Also the random mission generator is always good if you are looking for a quick challenge. As well as replaying missions trying to achieve the single-plan and hands-off achievements. The loadouts are varied and offer a decent sized arsenal. It is mostly reflective of what a police SWAT team would have available. One gameplay feature I like is how your team really practices good trigger discipline (single shots if possible). While the bad guys will often go full auto at the slightest of targets. One thing that is not completely apparent in the loadout section of the game is what effects do the equipment have on your team. You'll notice in cramped interiors, it takes the man with the M4 longer to train his rifle than the man weilding his pistol. But for those long corridor or outdoor shots, your Assaulter with his rifle is far more efficient than your rear guard weiding his shotgun. Sadly none of this is explicitly described in the loadout menu and will take some experimentation to figure out what the ideal loadout is based on your style of play and the mission. The graphics and sound are good for a game. It is definitely not a high fidelity sound and graphics visual masterpiece, but that really is not necessary. It is the gameplay which makes this game shine. There are various mods which revamp the sound experience if you are unhappy with the tone of the firearms. Overall, really fun game!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Incredibly satisfying game with challenging levels, yet easy to master mechanics. Very simple art style and gameplay that manages to feel rewarding everytime you roll through a level, watching your operators execute your plans and complete their objectives. The game comes with a ton of levels and once you beat those offers egregiously easy access to user created material to keep the game going.Pros:Great gameplay.Great value.Virtually infinite replayability with a built in feature to randomly generate levels.Simple, attractive art style.Enjoyable soundtrack.Easy to grasp concept.Cons:I genuinely can not think of one. They really have made a perfect game.I can confidently give this game a perfect 10/10 score. It does everything it promises and it does it very well.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Awesome game, simple graphics, 2D, and yet very fun. It's a tactical strategy game where you customize your own squad, names, callsigns, loadouts, and roles (like shield, stealth, assaulter, breacher and pointman) and assign them to missions, and there are a ton of missions, premade missions, campaigns, community-made missions, mission generator and mission editor as well. The replayability is enormous and you can just keep playing different missions for hours.Different objectives like hostages, bomb defusals, pure hostile killing, etc, The design of the plan system is very nice and well-made, you can plan out tactics and pause at any time of the game. You can make a whole plan from the start of the mission, or you can play a more real-time playstyle where your plan is improvised as the operation goes, or a combination of both.If you are interested in conducting anti-terrorist/crime operations(e.g. SWAT) and is not too picky with the graphics, you should definitely give this a try.  It's got the Rainbow Six/SWAT atmosphere but the gameplay style of XCOM converted to real-time.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Addictive little tactics game with some smooth action.  This game simulates a bust like on the Wire, or Hill Street Blues. Where the cops beat down the door and then run to catch the perps in the act, and stop them destroying the evidence, or killing hostages. I like how it builds up the anticipation of what lies behind a door, and then the thrill from the controlled burst of violence necessary to subdue whoever is in there. There are single missions and a campaign. The campaigns, so far, are really just loosely tied together single missions.  But, this is fine if you’re looking for action and tactics and not much story.The game has many mods and comes with a cool looking editor, for those who want to get lots of replay. I would love to see a sequel set in Rio de Janeiro or somewhere.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												My enjoyment of this game followed an inverted bell curve - at first I was elated. The dip came somewhere between my 20th and 30th mission, where the difficulty started ramping up faster than I could cope with. I was quite frustrated for a while but kept trying to wade forward. And sure enough, once my knowledge of the game mechanics accumulated past a certain critical mass it was only upwards on that bell curve, toward permanent satisfaction. To limit the length of this review, I'd like to touch up only on things that I didn't like as I'm sure the positives are thoroughly described by others. there are no collisions between units. While this makes the game easier, I kinda expected having to manage this aspect of CQB - avoiding a jam when moving in cramped spaces. And here instead you can stack your whole squad on one space like some sort of Shiva with 20 arms, wielding 8 guns, 2 tasers and a shield. And it's a very valid tactic. as an aside to the above, there is also no friendly fire though I don't mind. there are multi-layered levels (ex. a house with an additional floor) but time moves forward only on the floor you are observing. This is an engine deficiency acknowledged by the devs and it's here to stay. Sort of embarassing. the interface used for drawing paths is pretty clunky. It's hard to use precisely, and even harder if you're trying to map out a complicated plan in a tight space because of all the markers. It took me like 3 hours and some googling to figure out how to strafe. The option to "bend" an existing path is either missing or I haven't found it.  there is a fair amount of bugs, particularly related to handcuffing. in the hardest, endgame levels you are kinda undergunned and seriously struggling to defeat the body armor of enemies. I appreciate that police arsenals are not the same as military, yet it feels wrong. there is a bit too much randomness in the outcome of firefights. Even the best plan will sometimes be defeated by RNG.But yeah, in the end I agree with the Overwhelmingly Positive rating. This game will satisfy almost any fan of tactical combat. It's extremely addictive and feels rewarding to improve in.

												I had the pleasure of looking at DoorKickers way back in Alpha and then again at the full release version. I'm glad it made it all the way through. It reminds me a lot of the tactical planner in pre-Raven Shield Rainbow Six games. You can carefully plan out your teams entry into an area swarming of enemies and maybe even hostages or adapt a plan on the fly. It can be pretty challenging too! The game has a fair amount of pre-made content for the price and also offers a stage builder to extend that further. KillHouse Games provided me with a review copy to produce a first impressions video. If you'd like to see the game in motion and hear some more thoughts consider checking out the video below.

												It's a great take on top down tactical close quarters combat.  It has the feel of the game "Hotline Miami."  The controls overall were why I stopped playing, they felt wonky and couldn't control the angle of your LOS (line of sight) very well, which rendered the tactical element of the game almost useless.  The concept is there, and it could be a lot of fun if you master the control scheme, however, I am just too old to try and get it down.  Fans of the Rainbow Six series (the old ones) will be familiar with this type of game, and likely enjoy it.  Also there is a Rainbow Six mod, which I played with that will add even more familiarity to this game.  I recommend it but with hestitation that he controls are very difficult to get in the groove.  Get this for sure if it is on sale, and you are a fan of tactical gameplay.

Posted: November 11, 2014
												Team Alpha, go! Bravo, engage!Pros:- Doorkickers has a very great tactical element to it, allowing you to utilize unit sight lines to spy corners before entering and taking out the baddies before shots are fired. Using multiple units for cover and movement through doorways, flashing, flanking is very fun and very satisfying when it all goes according to the plan in your mind. - The different classes to combine on missions is very interesting and with mobility meters could spell the difference between a good outcome on a mission or a very fatal end.- Utilization of "Go-Codes" is always exciting when you are able to time your plan sequences in a smooth, fluid execution.- There is a SKILL tree and Doctrine points to purchase weapons and gear (only once) for all of your units to use- Lots of maps and creatable content to share with Steam friends and community. Cons:- I have to admit, sometimes the units can be a bit finnicky, and it gets a bit frustrating; there are two tangos in a large room on the other side of a locked door you cannot flashbang through - breaching with a hammer, lockpick, or breaching charge takes too much time to set up, you send a man through and direct his sight line to sweep, but instead of firing on the first guy he sees on side A, sweeps and shoots man in corner B instead and leaves the first man he sees in the shadows. Alongside the factor of friendly fire sight lines, its frustrating when you have 2 of your own units stacked on top of each other, but one will not fire in his designated direction due to a teammate being directly on top of him.- I've found that enemy units are able to fire simultaneously and hit my units while they are in a line, while my units cannot fire through each other. Something I think will be patched in the future.- Another issue I'm having is pathing selections: there are times where lines will overlap in a hallway and you wnat to change the sight line of ONE of your units, but you can't select his pathing line because the OTHER guys' line is on top of his. I tried to lock one unit's path with SHIFT, but doesn't seem to work. Something that can be fixed.Conclusion:All in all, I REALLY do enjoy the game. For $20? Sure. I honestly feel the game's INCLUDED content could have been more, the campaigns are a bit short, but the replayability with different tactics is refreshing. The focus on community map content is a bit harrowing, as I'm not one to really have time to download and configure all of it to work. I also feel that each class should have their own type of special ability in relation with the skill trees, instead of just access to a certain type of primary weapon. Different stat fluctuations, maybe? I don't know. It's still a great game to kill time and terrorists with.

												If the trailer interests you in the game, then get it. It's as good as it looks.If you liked Frozen Synapse but wish it was a little more organic and less chess-like, this is your game.If you like re-playability through perfection, then 90% of the scenarios have medals that you can earn by beating it under one of three conditions. (You can do them all at the same time or in separate runs). 1) Lone Wolf - Complete the stage with one team member deployed. 2) Real Time - Do not manually pause the game from start to the end of the operation.3) One Plan - Create a tactical plan for your team, then succeed using that plan without any interference from you.Also a 3 star rating for each level. Did you beat it within mission par time? Did you lose any men?Tons of scenarios to keep you busy (100+), and even a couple campaign modes of increasing difficulty. (Not really any story, but there's links between each level)Lots of backdrops. Cruise ships, Grocery Stores, Bars, Police Stations, Autoshops, docks, subways, vacation homes... you name it.Possible Scenarios: Bomb, Hostage, Elimination, Execution (Hostage but with a timer), and Robbery.This game is amazing. Oh yeah and there's a mission editor and Steam Workshop support. WHAT. Get this game.

												Highly tactical game that is essentially about finding the best way to get your officers to kill all the Druggies, Terrorists, Junkies, etcetera. The action can be fast and brutal, or slow and methodical, with the multiple classes, dozens upon dozens of missions, and all manner of weapons and potential ways to win in the fast-paced gameplay of Door Kickers.Open-ended tactical action with loads of potential gameplay, PLUS Steam Workshop and an active modding community. This didn't win 'Best Tactics 2014' for nothing (Rock Paper Shotgun), and I say it shows. Rainbow Six if it was top-down and you were a floating policeman god, some may say (There's also mods to make it Rainbow Six). There's much more, but this is just the tip of the iceberg, I say.If you like what you're reading, I say go take a look at some (more, if you already have) videos before deciding if you want to spend money on this (because it's smart, of course). Highly recommended for fans of tactical shooters and strategy games alike.Apologies for any major issues or minor errors, I should be asleep. But Door Kickers.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												 First "tactical" game I've seen in a while that actually deserves the name. One of maybe three games I've played ever, wherein you could actually use real-world tactics, and those tactics not only work, but they work in-game, for the same reasons they work in real life. Button-hooks, cross-overs, "slicing the pie", etc. etc. This could be used as a kind of "sim-lite" for real-world operators-in-training, who just want to see tactics in action, while exploring why they work. Beyond that, it's a fairly entertaining game, giving you all the gear choices, squad-building, and planning that you need for a game to actually be "tactical", a term that is either misused these days, or avoided for fear of losing the instant gratification and hand-holding market. With both one-off missions, several campaigns (with more to come, apparently), random mission generator, and Steam Workshop support, there's endless hours of play available. I do have some relatively minor complaints, though. For one, any tactical game that uses a weapon and gear unlock system breaks my immersion just a tad. Real world units don't have to unlock weapons and gear. They simply use what they feel best fits the task at hand. So I kind of wish they would have gone the classic Rainbow Six route, where everything is at your disposal from the get-go. Also, there are some rather unrealistic balancing issues. Targets wearing body armor are human bullet sponges. I've watched in amusement, as my full-armored operator unloaded round after round of 5.56 from an M4 into one of these vested "tangos" at point-blank range, only to watch the target giggle, scratch his nuts, wink at my wife, and blow my up-armored operator away with a few rounds from his sub-gun. I'm sorry, but no vest exists that will stop a full-powered rifle round without at least incurring incapacitating trauma on the wearer. But no mind, it's just a game after all. Just frustrating at times. I've also gotten the sense that the developers understood "rate-of-fire" to be more important/significant than stopping power, which is ridiculous. I'm not claiming to be one of them, but if you talk to anyone with any experience in a job where firearms use and training was in the job description, they'll tell you that 99.9% of the time, you're going to use that full-auto weapon in semi-auto mode, and you're trained that way for a reason. Accuracy and stopping power are what keep you alive, and rate-of-fire negates accuracy, and therefor also negates stopping power (because you're not hitting anything), as it increases. But again, not a big deal. It's just kind of awkward when you get the sense that your MP5 on full-auto, is somehow proving more effective than that M4 with well-placed shots.All in all, this is a great game, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys tactics and planning! I've already put an obscene number of hours into this one, with many more to come!

Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game has a lot of annoying UI problems - most of which are minor, but they add up - but other than that it's pretty good.The game mechanics are solid, if a bit unrealistic in parts. For example, enemies can hit you with grenades when you're inside a house and they're outside, down the street. (The grenade appears to go over the exterior wall of a house and through the roof.) Cover isn't very consistent. Some cars give you cover; others don't. It has an iron-man mode, which I appreciate. The unit classes are a bit unbalanced in that some are much more useful than others, but it doesn't matter too much.The game has you executing civilians without warning and without giving them a chance to surrender, so you basically play a bad cop in a police state, but then we're all used to games being murder simulators anyway. The game calls the criminals "terrorists", which is about as accurate as calling them "communists". I'm slightly bothered by the promotion of terrorist hysteria and the dilution of the word "terrorist" into meaninglessness, but oh well.The map designs are pretty good, but it seems that you either need luck or prescience to beat some of them without casualties, which is a bit unfortunate. The game comes with an editor that lets you make your own scenarios and share them for other people to play.The game doesn't have a manual or a decent tutorial, but you can probably figure it out.The developer is very active in the forums and frequently responds to questions, which I greatly appreciate, but I'm not sure how good he is at fixing bugs. (I know of at least one problem that he said would be fixed "in the next update", but that was in August 2014 and it's still not fixed as of June 2015. Maybe he forgot or maybe he changed his mind. I don't know.)The existing campaigns and missions seem like they'll provide at least 20 hours of play, and there are supposed to be more campaigns coming. I don't know whether the developer will make good on that promise, but it's nice that the game is supposed to continue to grow in the future.Overall, the game has lots of little problems that detract from the enjoyment but even so it's still fun.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Do I recommend this game? Yes. Absolutely. Here's why:-Intuitive leveling system; As you level up, you get points to spend on your trooper's skills, like better "draw speed" indoors, or the ability to make anyone using a silenced weapon hold their fire if they aren't in direct danger. Pretty rad.-A kind of currency: You earn stars for completing levels, the better you do, the more stars you earn, and you spend those stars on weapons and equipment for your troopers.-Can be played real-time, or with the "Pause" option, for those who want to take a tiny bit more time to think about their plan.-PERMADEATH: This is something that a lot of games don't do anymore. If you are in a Campaign (and only in campaigns), and a trooper dies in a mission, you lose that trooper (and his individual level and skills) forever, and he's replaced with a green trooper.-A pretty fun soundtrack-A small, but adequate variety of missions: Elimination, Hostage Rescue, VIP Escort, Bomb Defusal, House Calls, Drug Busts, and Arrest Warrants. (Some missions may have multiple properties of each kind of mission, like a bomb defusal mission might have hostages and evidence to gather (drugs)).Now here's why I WOULDN'T recommend it to some:-For those with short attention spans (this guy..) this game can get pretty dull at times.-Very frustrating level of difficulty later on. Enemies have strong body armor and spam grenades, which has the capacity to instantly kill your troopers or kill civilians, resulting in a more difficult (or instantly failed) mission.-High learning curve: Do NOT, I repeat, DO NOT expect to play as well as the player in the videos, even if you're a strategy game guru. This game punishes hasty mistakes to the max, and early newcomers will have a hard time adapting to the controls and gameplay.There are plenty of other reasons for me to recommend this game or not to others, but these are my main ones, and the reason I love/hate this game at any given time. "Tango Down!"

Posted: May 24, 2015
												 First "tactical" game I've seen in a while that actually deserves the name. One of maybe three games I've played ever, wherein you could actually use real-world tactics, and those tactics not only work, but they work in-game, for the same reasons they work in real life. Button-hooks, cross-overs, "slicing the pie", etc. etc. This could be used as a kind of "sim-lite" for real-world operators-in-training, who just want to see tactics in action, while exploring why they work. Beyond that, it's a fairly entertaining game, giving you all the gear choices, squad-building, and planning that you need for a game to actually be "tactical", a term that is either misused these days, or avoided for fear of losing the instant gratification and hand-holding market. With both one-off missions, several campaigns (with more to come, apparently), random mission generator, and Steam Workshop support, there's endless hours of play available. I do have some relatively minor complaints, though. For one, any tactical game that uses a weapon and gear unlock system breaks my immersion just a tad. Real world units don't have to unlock weapons and gear. They simply use what they feel best fits the task at hand. So I kind of wish they would have gone the classic Rainbow Six route, where everything is at your disposal from the get-go. Also, there are some rather unrealistic balancing issues. Targets wearing body armor are human bullet sponges. I've watched in amusement, as my full-armored operator unloaded round after round of 5.56 from an M4 into one of these vested "tangos" at point-blank range, only to watch the target giggle, scratch his nuts, wink at my wife, and blow my up-armored operator away with a few rounds from his sub-gun. I'm sorry, but no vest exists that will stop a full-powered rifle round without at least incurring incapacitating trauma on the wearer. But no mind, it's just a game after all. Just frustrating at times. I've also gotten the sense that the developers understood "rate-of-fire" to be more important/significant than stopping power, which is ridiculous. I'm not claiming to be one of them, but if you talk to anyone with any experience in a job where firearms use and training was in the job description, they'll tell you that 99.9% of the time, you're going to use that full-auto weapon in semi-auto mode, and you're trained that way for a reason. Accuracy and stopping power are what keep you alive, and rate-of-fire negates accuracy, and therefor also negates stopping power (because you're not hitting anything), as it increases. But again, not a big deal. It's just kind of awkward when you get the sense that your MP5 on full-auto, is somehow proving more effective than that M4 with well-placed shots.All in all, this is a great game, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys tactics and planning! I've already put an obscene number of hours into this one, with many more to come!

Posted: June 13, 2015
												If the trailer interests you in the game, then get it. It's as good as it looks.If you liked Frozen Synapse but wish it was a little more organic and less chess-like, this is your game.If you like re-playability through perfection, then 90% of the scenarios have medals that you can earn by beating it under one of three conditions. (You can do them all at the same time or in separate runs). 1) Lone Wolf - Complete the stage with one team member deployed. 2) Real Time - Do not manually pause the game from start to the end of the operation.3) One Plan - Create a tactical plan for your team, then succeed using that plan without any interference from you.Also a 3 star rating for each level. Did you beat it within mission par time? Did you lose any men?Tons of scenarios to keep you busy (100+), and even a couple campaign modes of increasing difficulty. (Not really any story, but there's links between each level)Lots of backdrops. Cruise ships, Grocery Stores, Bars, Police Stations, Autoshops, docks, subways, vacation homes... you name it.Possible Scenarios: Bomb, Hostage, Elimination, Execution (Hostage but with a timer), and Robbery.This game is amazing. Oh yeah and there's a mission editor and Steam Workshop support. WHAT. Get this game.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												Highly tactical game that is essentially about finding the best way to get your officers to kill all the Druggies, Terrorists, Junkies, etcetera. The action can be fast and brutal, or slow and methodical, with the multiple classes, dozens upon dozens of missions, and all manner of weapons and potential ways to win in the fast-paced gameplay of Door Kickers.Open-ended tactical action with loads of potential gameplay, PLUS Steam Workshop and an active modding community. This didn't win 'Best Tactics 2014' for nothing (Rock Paper Shotgun), and I say it shows. Rainbow Six if it was top-down and you were a floating policeman god, some may say (There's also mods to make it Rainbow Six). There's much more, but this is just the tip of the iceberg, I say.If you like what you're reading, I say go take a look at some (more, if you already have) videos before deciding if you want to spend money on this (because it's smart, of course). Highly recommended for fans of tactical shooters and strategy games alike.Apologies for any major issues or minor errors, I should be asleep. But Door Kickers.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												This is probably one of the most satisfying strategy games of all time.I just finished a mission with one single plan, without pausing, and got 3 stars. I felt like a badass, and I am now going to watch the replay and gloat.It took me a bit to get my head around the controls, but now they work great.I've only just started playing, so I'm on easier single missions, but there is just so much gameplay here between the included missions, campaigns, and various mods.In addition, I'm usually only coordinating 2 agents. There are a much more difficult missions with many more agents to plan and coordinate with, so there is some seriously deep tactical gameplay here.This looks very similar to Breach & Clear, so if you thought, like me, that it was a copy or something, you were wrong. While it has a free pause, so it can feel turn based, you can also go real time. It allows for a range of playstyles depending on your tastes. In addition, the lack of grid based movement ends up being a huge plus.Buy it.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												Probably the closest we'll ever get to another SWAT game. You get a selection of weapons and equipment to complete missions, from stun guns to stinger grenades to M4s. Then you're asked to complete levels in times that would make the SAS sweat. Tasks can range from rescuing hostages to defusing bombs, to simply killng all enemies in the level. Intricate planning is a must - one mistake and that trooper you've been so proud of will be eating dirt in a second. You're not tougher than the enemies, so be smarter. It's a tough, rewarding, fun strategy game with oodles of content (single levels, campaigns, and a mission generator). Well worth full price, and on sale, it's a steal.

								This game is brilliant. For a game still in development, it is surprisingly good. One of my favourite top-down games ever. Easy enough to understand, but with a great deal of versatility in regards to how you wish to play out each mission. Do you go slowly from room to room, checking past each door with a spy camera, or just charge in with shotguns, grenades and breaching charges? This game can also be quite challenging, which means completion of a difficult mission actually feels like an achievment. I'm hoping as development goes forward the variety of weapons, tools, tactics and missions  will all increase, so you can play the game entirely your way.

												Doorkickers is a awesome game!  You have to plan and execute Missions for a Police Squad. You can plan the whole execution before you start the mission or change the plan while the Mission is running. You have many options how you get the job done. 												I've got a little more than an hour into this game, and I have to say, it is thrilling. It reminds me a lot of the old SWAT2 title, but far more approchable. Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door Kickers is a top-down stradegy game where you control SWAT members, each with his own stats.BETA VERSION: Some stuff here is subject to change, so when you play it may be different! These are my opinions about it all!Pros:+Members have different stats that increase as they gain experience through missions.+Style and elements are very good and work with the game exceptionally well.+Take down hostiles however you want, stealth or guns blazing (which is difficult)+Weapons and Armor are unlockable as you beat levels!+Badge can be customized off real ones, like NYPD+Random Mission Generator is fun to mess with adn what you will use the most, probably+Very Neat Replay system, enjoyable to watch yourself decimate your enemies in slow motion+STEAM WORKSHOP is amazing with thisNeither:-+The exeperience system takes a long time to get the breacher and Stealth class and requires more play time to unlock.-+Workshop is (Version 0.1.1) currently broken and hardly any good mods work :(-+Bugs, but it is in BETA so can't complainCons:-The pathing system has a hard time getting past obstacles like benchs, etc.-Armor is a pain to unlock, besides the Extended Armor which is 5 stars.-Random Mission Generator stars dont actually give you Roster stars, but still give XP.-Some enemies can see troops while the troops can't see them WHEN they are right in front of him. ie around a corner or in a room he is facing.-No trooper will ever die if you use the restart button. Guy dies, restart mission and you have him back.Overall, Fun for the stradegy people out there and a very fine and playable game right now. 8/10

Anybody can jump on a first person shooter and go for a run but this is the first game that even comes close to the immersion that the SWAT franchise gave us in terms of entry team decision making. Do you want to go in quietly and plan every single corner down to the tiniest detail? Or do you want to throw thirty flash-bangs and fill the room with lead?This game is totally epic and I was not expecting it to be this fun. Pros+plan your route right down to individual arcs and tasks+cause mayhem or sneak in with silenced weapons+HUGE replayability Cons-would love a bit more gear and weapon customizationGameplay 9/10Tactical options 8/10Soundtrack 10/10Go kick some doors

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Doorkickers feels a little bit like Rainbow Six 3, without the FPS part.You manage a squad of 2+ (depending on the mission) officers who have to clear a building, secure evidence or rescue hostages.Before starting the actual mission, you are to forge a plan of how to tackle the situation.You can give orders to each officer individually so that in the end they work together to clear the building as quickly and safely as possible.You may also give each officer different weapons, or a completely different class.Need a shielder? No problem.Or rather a breacher? You got it.A stealther? Sure.If you are not satisfied with certain aspects of the game, the modding community is doing their job for sure.From different/new weapons or armours, to completely new classes and obviously loads of user made maps.The cartoonish graphics are definitely no throw off. You will be way too focused on your tactics trying to keep your officers alive than to check out the beautiful flower pots in the bathroom.Just don't go thinking "Easy peasy". You will have your squad killed easier than one would think. A proper planning phase is half a victory.Now grab your gear and get on the truck. We are Oscar Mike in 5. Barricaded suspects holding a hostage which you need to rescue!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Door Kickers is a top-down strategy game that puts you in a command of SWAT team. You have your SWAT team on disposal and you need to kick many doors (hence the name) and kill many bad guys.You can plan your assault and/or move your SWAT members in real time, also you can pause the time to make precise instructions for troops.The biggest plus of this game is modding. This game is not out too long but there are many mods: total conversion, skin mods, weapon mods, levels which can be published to workshop from in-game so this adds to great, infinite replayability.So yeah, I recommend this gameTIP: don't give names to your squad members of your family and friends because they will get brutally murdered by a terrorist that you missed in that one corner where you didn't expect him

Posted: October 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door Kickers is basically the original SWAT/Rainbow Six from a top-down perspective.It has simplified the gameplay for a more casual approach.It supports mods and you can already download the Rainbow Six mod for a nostalgic trip down memory lane.Its simplicity does leave you craving for a proper Rainbow Six game, which we all know is not going to happen anytime soon.Hopefully a potential sequel to Door Kickers will have more complex ai and more depth.Buy if you are a fan of tactical games with more time spent planning ahead rather than the actual action.Avoid if you don't have patience.

Posted: February 9, 2015
												Okay, I've been sitting here glued to my screen for 3 hours straight and I'm approaching level 20 and just wanted to stop for a minute and tell you why I love this game and why I think that you just might love it too.First, if you loved the planning of Rainbow Six and the strategy of the old school SWAT games, stop reading my review and go buy this...it's the closest thing, I think, that we're going to get to a spiritual successor. This game has it all: strategy, great firefights (even though it's top down, the gun fights feel ferocious), a nice bit of customization, and a great developer that continually supports the game (there was another recent update adding more levels and bug fixes).Also, it's worth noting that this game is in BETA (I think) and is as stable as I've ever seen; zero crashes or bugs for me thus far. This game is easy to pick up and hard to master. But, before you know it, you'll be laying way points, tossing flashbangs, and blowing doors off their hinges like a pro. The first time you storm a building from two entrances, tossing flashbangs and double tapping baddies, all while a sniper lays down cover fire, you'll be grinning like an idiot. And when your team dies because your point man forgot to check his corners, you'll happily restart and do it all again.5/5

Posted: May 7, 2015
												It took a few hours for me to begin truly enjoying Door Kickers, and it was only after: A. I began to see it more as a puzzle game than a tactical shooter and B. stopped deploying 2-8 exact clones and diversified my squad.  This game has high replay value, a nicely paced learning curve, and creates genuine thrills when a plan comes together.  I have a few small complaints (mainly the inconsistency of the AI towards hostages), but for its price this was a steal for the hours I will continue to get out of it.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												This is probably one of the most satisfying strategy games of all time.I just finished a mission with one single plan, without pausing, and got 3 stars. I felt like a badass, and I am now going to watch the replay and gloat.It took me a bit to get my head around the controls, but now they work great.I've only just started playing, so I'm on easier single missions, but there is just so much gameplay here between the included missions, campaigns, and various mods.In addition, I'm usually only coordinating 2 agents. There are a much more difficult missions with many more agents to plan and coordinate with, so there is some seriously deep tactical gameplay here.This looks very similar to Breach & Clear, so if you thought, like me, that it was a copy or something, you were wrong. While it has a free pause, so it can feel turn based, you can also go real time. It allows for a range of playstyles depending on your tastes. In addition, the lack of grid based movement ends up being a huge plus.Buy it.

Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome, who doesn't want to break a door down and blow a terrorist head off?I've played the game for a couple hours so far, it fun and very interesting, however, remember that this is still an alpha, so not even a beta yet, so don't expect everything to be polished or the game to be at its full. The game can be pretty frustrating at times, for example I don't understand the use of stealth weapons, it doesn't change anything, enemies hear you and come to investigate. I hate this, i like playing stealthy by as soon as one shot from a stealth weapon  goes off, enemies come to see what the noise was then♥♥♥♥♥♥turns into cluster ♥♥♥♥ central. I do hope they actually fix this, if they did then this game would definitely be on my top 5 game list. There's this a lot missing from the game, for example not all of the upgrades are available, there's no campaign so you just go through different stages and shoot at people. One of the most frustrating missions are hostage rescue missions, at first they are nice and all but after a couple stages, they start executing hostages, so if you break a door or shoot at someone, you have 5 seconds to reach the hostages before they are executed,  which isn't easy in a big house/office... Also, it seems SWAT doesn't care much for hostages, if they see an enemy and there's a hostage in-between them, they just shoot at them and kill the hostage, which is especially annoying since if you kill a hostage, or a hostage dies, it's mission failed. Don't expect it to be a Call of Duty like game where one person takes on an entire building full of terrorists, you will almost always be out-numbered so you have to plan ahead of time, and be ready to adapt when things don't go your way.  I would recommend this game if you like games like XCOM but remember, this is still an alpha and there's a lot missing.

Not to mention that the semi-randomized location of your enemies makes it a lot less useful to plan your missions out ahead of time- a particular plan might work on one run but fail in the exact same spot the next, and you just have to keep restarting in the hopes that your enemies will be in the right rooms. It's frustrating because it's such a challenging and rewarding game otherwise, but there's a few little things that make you feel like you're being punished for nothing, and in such a high-stakes, difficult game, those things can really break the experience

Posted: January 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Easily one of the most intense top down games I've ever played. The ability to have multiple entry strategies whether that be placing a charge on the door, shooting the lock, or tossing in a flashbang makes the outcomes of just a single room almost immeasurable. The AI is great as well. If you take a more stealthy approach, the enemies may not be watching the door waiting for you. But if you charge through the house blasting everyone with shotguns, expect them to be in cover waiting for your squad to barge in. Also, even though on the menu it says its in the "Alpha" phase you could mistake this for a finished game. I've spent almost 4 hours in it I think and haven't seen a single bug or experienced an issue. The best 15 dollars I've ever spent. I hope its finished soon. If you can drop 15 dollars, put it into this game. You won't be dissappointed.

Posted: April 1, 2016
												Door Kickers is just a great, refreshing take on the old tactical "move your men around and shoot"-style of game. It is what you would hope for as the next installment of XCOM or Jagged Alliance 2. Gone are the tedious hour-hungry turn-based mechanics of yesteryear. Gone are the unnecessary numbers and virtual die rolls. Instead you get fast-paced, easy-to-play excitement from start to end. The end unfortunately comes too soon. More content would have been nice, and the third party downloads are unfortunately very lacking. I hope the sequel will provide much more. And - BTW - beware the almost uannounced permadeath in campaign mode! Realizing that your loyal Lieutenant has suddenly and irreversably disappeared from your roster is not what I call enjoyable fun!

Posted: April 28, 2015
												Door Kickers is an excellent blend of strategy, tactics, puzzle soving, and a nice blend of RPG elements such as character leveling. It has the feeling of games like XCOM or Jagged Alliance, but it's much faster paced. Each level can be replayed, and there are different challanges for each mission. Posted: June 21, 2015
												Almost immediately after I’m spotted, the bad guys kill the hostage. I take a brief moment to unleash a string of curses and rack my brain. There must be another route I can take, another plan that would give this scenario a happy ending. I tinker with the map and reset, and soon I hear a meaty splat as the hostage gets killed again.Door Kickers is a game about cops kicking down doors, and these doors are a lot of fun to kick down. It is also very hard, and I love it for that. Played from a top-down, pausable view, this is the game that happens when Rainbow Six’s planning stage grows up and finds a home on a modern engine. It is also one of the most finely detailed, cleverly executed puzzle games I’ve played in years.Fog of warEach mission in Door Kickers starts with a deployment phase. Within this phase, I see the target house as a set of blueprints, atop which I can change shooters’ equipment and starting positions. As missions become more complex, the deployment phase becomes where I make some of my most important decisions. Door Kickers is a great tactical game because it is a great question generator:Are there narrow hallways? Will all firefights be up close? Are there hostages? Do I have sharpshooter support? Is there furniture? Is there evidence to save? Do the bad guys have bigger guns than me? Every piece of information changes the ideal approach and forces adaptation.After the deployment screen, the mission begins with time paused. From the paused overview, I drag paths for officers to follow, change the direction they’re covering, and order them to breach a door. This simple array of options becomes a complicated choreography of death pretty fast. In later missions, my eight officers follow a dance routine with hundreds of steps, pauses, shooting angles, and go-codes. Giving these orders is straightforward and malleable, but the interface is missing some important functions. If I give two units overlapping paths (walking single-file next to a wall, for example), I don’t have any way of selecting one trail over another when I want to edit it. To work around this, I have my units walk behind and to the side of each other, but that’s frequently a poor decision, tactics-wise. With eight officers in a narrow hallways, it also gets downright silly.Some of the other limitations of this system are simply built into the game engine: there’s no crouching or leaning, so the game’s combat takes place entirely on a two-dimensional plane with straight lines. It rarely feels as flat as it is, but there are occasions where I would love to stack a crouched unit under a standing unit, and these are the times when the game’s simulation feels most like a puzzle game and least like a camera looking down on a real-life SWAT situation.

Posted: June 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Super little game. Fun enough at the moment that even if development stopped for some reason I'd not feel I'd wasted any money and they're adding plenty of other features/content as development goes on anyway.If you played the old Rainbow 6 then it has similarities to the planning phase of that but can play/pause as you go (and control the officers while they're running your plan for desperate tweaks etc); I'd be tempted to compare the positioning etc to Frozen Synapse too.  The idea is to achieve the goal of the level; at the moment one of, kill everyone, rescue the hostage/s, make the arrest or disarm the bomb.  There are other goals to get better ratings on each level which are to beat a certain time and to keep as many of your chaps up as possible.Advancement is both by individual cops gaining in ability and rank, and "Squad Doctrine" group training options.Gear is selectable both by a class (which can be changed per mission) and choices within that class- which specific guns, armour and gadgets your chap will carry into the mission.  Some of the choices at the moment are fairly irrelevant and down to small preferences, others will have a big effect on how you go through the mission.POST RELEASE additional comments:There are a selection of single missions; randomly generated single missions; mods from the workshop and campaigns.  The single missions are sort of training for the campaigns really, both yourself, and leveling your troops/unlocking gear.  The campaigns themselves are perma-death but with restarts though there is iron-man mode which doesn't allow restarting. All in all a pretty vast amount of prepared content and then there are all the mods and randomly generated content making for a pretty near infinite game...and you'll almost certainly want to do individual bits multiple times too.I've gone through the single missions multiple times now and there's still tactical improvements, nuances etc to learn.  They've updated adding more content and more is still to come.  If you like tactical stuff just do yourself a favour and buy this game.

Posted: February 6, 2015
												This game is a completely hidden gem. The content is massive and it's completely unassuming. I have been fooled by the top down 2D'ness of the game. Yet behind that facade of what might seem like a "cheap" game, are 3 campaigns, *80* (yes, EIGHTY) single missions with a variety of modes like 'Terrorist Hunt', 'Hostage Rescue', and a random mission generator to boot. Not only that, player made custom missions can be downloaded through the workshop.A variety of equipment are available, and it's extremely realistic. The added fact that all rifles are fired on single shot merrits mentioning, as firing assault rifles on full auto are only in movies or untrained armies. This game in my opinion, is far better than SWAT 4 or even the original Rainbow Six series were.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												Doorkickers in an awesome semi-realistic top-down pause/play Urban Ops tactical planning game (a lot of words, i know), focusing on police and counter-terrorism scenarios. It has exceptional value for your money, and the devs are decent enough to actually bring a good game out of early acces. That shouldn't have to be a plus, but it is.Your SWAT team is fully levlable with it's own skill tree, seperate from the leveling of each individual team member, and the unlocking of new gear for your team, which adds to the feeling of progression and depth of the game. There are a LOT of ways to complete most levels, and as you unlock new gear you can go back and solve a scenario in a new and better way, improving replayability. Your team members die permanently (and is replaced by a rookie police officer) if you don't restart a mission where someone died, which gives every tactical decission you make a distinct feeling of importance. For someone with basic experience with military urban ops tactics, gameplay feels intuitive and realistic in that real life techniques and equipment are successfull when applied apropriately within the game. It's rewarding that I can jump straight into the game, learn the controlls, and instantly see how a good plan works, and a bad plan don't, and know EXACTLY why.One of the few problems i have with the game (which is completely subjective, and perhaps even a part of the intended difficulty) is that as the maps become bigger and the enemies more numeorus it becomes VERY tedious to make a working plan beforehand, and you basically have to "test" your way through the level. Another problem I have is that it gets problematic to controll bigger teams when you want them to walk the same path but perform different actions and cover different sectors, because their waypoints and routes overlap and create an unmanagable cluster. There should be a better way to toggle between the units and finalize/hide certain units' actions (maybe there is, but i missed it?).Another thing I wish was improved is the intelligence and behviour of the AI enemies. Considering they are hardened terrorists and seasoned criminals they're pretty stupid. This is really a realism issue, and not a gameplay issue, as I do mostly enjoy the game and it's dificulty as it is.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												So ill start this review of with a small story.So about a year go I was trying to choose between whether to buy Door Kickers or Breach and Clear during a sale, to me they both looked really interesting and fun to play so it wasnt an easy choice, but eventually I decided to buy Breach and Clear. I downloaded it, hit play and started to play, I really enjoyed the gameplay that it gave me but it was to short and didnt have much variety in the equipment I could give my soldiers, so I was still curious about Door Kickers and really wanted to play it, so about a year later I purchased Door Kickers. I started Playing Door Kickers and I immediately new this game was far superior to Breach and Clear, It contained much more content and variety in gameplay, as you have a much wider range in how you will will breach a building and what equipment you will use doing so. If you Have Breach and Clear and you enjoy it, Door kickers is 100% for you, or if you are trying to decide between Breach and Clear and Door Kickers, I would personally choose Door Kickers, I am not saying Breach and Clear is  a bad game i just think Door kickers is much better.One thing before I get into what is good and bad about the game I just want to mention something about the price-PRICE- I got Door Kickers for like 3$ or something and it is DEFINITELY worth that amount but the game is usually 20$, and I think this is pushing it a little to much as there are many other games out there for this amount that contain much more content, but if Top Down, Tactical games are your thing This is worth the 20$ -Now to what is Good and Bad about Door Kickers--PROS-- Lots of Variety (In how you breach Buildings and map types etc)- Provides hours of fun tactical gameplay- Many Primary and Secondary weapons to choose from- Nice graphics for a Top Down game- Easy to Run (You dont need Optimus Prime to be able to run it)- Easy to learn controls (also very smooth)- Can play custom maps from workshop - Can offer a real challenge on some maps - Plenty of missions-CONS- - Doesnt really have a storyline- When multiple troops paths cross or are close together it can be hard to tell a troop which way to look etc- A little expensive, but if you like topdown tactical games or its on sale its worth itOverall I think this game is one of the best games you will find in its genre, best suited for people that enjoy tactical gameplay, and the biggest downfall is its price even though its basically worth the price

Posted: June 16, 2015
												Really fun game to play!Looks?Reminds me of GTA 2  but with better graphics.Controls?Your mouse is almost exclusively sufficient. Keyboard use only for Go codes (A, B, C, D), sniper fire and some CTRL (locked view) and SHIFT key to highlight only selected paths. There are minor problems with complicated plans when lots of paths overlaps (even using SHIFFT) but TBH you can always be more precisie or just fix it when action goes live. Diversity of missions?More than enough. Bombs disarming, hostage rescue, VIP escorting, arresting bad guys, dope raids and simple enemy elimination.Guns and equipment?Quite a selection, especially gun wise but almost everything must be unlocked. Still when you find the fitting gun for all of your classes the selection will be just between classes (at least that was my case). Good guys?Well there are only three main stats for each officer and they are progressing without your choice but you can feel the difference between good and bad shooter especially with bad aiming gun. Bad guys?Enought to make it interesting but could be quite more. AI is quite good and on default missions there is several spawn points for bad guys, so it makes it more interesting.Maps?Plenty of different and really challenging ones.Is it tactical?Hell yeah it is ... but when you master most of the missions and use of pause you can kill everyone with one guy ... mostly. I had a lot of sneaky situations and they are planned to ambush you if you are not carefull. Some rage but no rage quits and that pleasant feeling when you finally do this.Replayibilty?With random missions and maps generator? Big. With steam workshop and plenty of maps, missions, guns, unit looks etc.? Quite bigger. Is it worth it?Hell yeah! I bought it for half the nominal price and I am more then satisfied of fun per eurocent ratio :-D

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												very easy to learn as the controls are quite simple, but quite an in depth game thats highly addictive.one thing i really love about this game is that it takes about 3 seconds to load to the main menu, after which everything instantly loads the second you click it. that means i can load up and be straight into it within a very quick amount of time.drawing a path for your team to follow is quite fluid, if your wobbly on the mouse your teams path will be too.insert commands easily onto that path, so they will CLEAR !  a room before moving on, strafe a certain direction, or wait for a go code.use the single missions to level up your team, unlock better weapons, shields, armor, tools etc by earning stars. once something is unlocked its free to assign to any other team member.once your team is good enough you can start doing campaigns.theres virtually hundreds of maps to choose from, and a steam workshop to add even more gear and maps.unlock new squad types like assaulter, breacher, shield and improve them by earning doctrine points to spend on perks for each class.weapon type and loadout will have a big effect on how your team maneuvers, its fire rate, accuracy, stopping power or clip size.assaulting an airplane to save some hostages? maybe the pistols will allow you to maneuver around easier and change targets quicker to fire off a few well placed rounds rather than trying to use a clumsy shotgun or spray machine gun fire about.use a camera under the door to spot targets, blow open the door, flashbang, give the go signal with a "go code" to assault rooms full of terrorists from different doorways, save the hostages, disarm bombs, and taze the guy you have a warrant for.i give it 80/100 dead terrorists

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												GREAT game that was well worth the price (woo holiday sale!) Planning out your unit's movements and facings is surprisingly intuitive, and the go-code mechanic helps keep your guys coordinated. Your units feel competently trained but not godlike, and the enemies are challenging without being frustrating. Pretty much every time one of my units dies, it's immediately apparent it's because I forgot to plan for some variable/check that corner/messed up my pathing/some other personal error rather than my units not shooting straight.Each officer can be customized with different class, weapons, support options, armor, and a tool, and each choice feels meaningful. For example, if I want the officer to stay in the back of an open area and provide cover, I'll make him an assault and give him a carbine for range and stopping power and heavy armor since he won't have to move as much. If I want to run the same officer through a drug bust, I'll change him to a pointman (stealth once I've unlocked it), give him a silenced pistol and light armor so he can quickly and quietly run through the hideout and secure the evidence before it's destroyed.The game almost feels puzzle like, in that it encourages players to find the optimum route through each map to guarantee success no matter enemy placement (something the game tests by mixing up where the enemies are on each map) with a well though out plan, rather than simply winging it on the fly (although that is possible, especially if you want to make effective use of the spy cam). Notably, the player is rewarded on some maps for executing the perfect plan by planning everything once, then hitting go and doing nothing but watch the action. It maintains a good balance in difficulty as well. The game rarely feels too easy, but it also rarely feels frustrating or overwhelming in difficulty.Progression is surprisngly well thought out, starting players on a simple kill house with a handful of badguys and a pair of officers, cutting their teeth in before introducing door entry, different classes, hostage rescue, and arresting/escorting mechanics.I haven't messed with the ingame editor yet, but its very presence almost guarantees near infinite replayability. Currently, there is a wide selection of challenging single missions, and four campaigns (a string of 5 or 6 missions), with a 5th having a confirmed release date and more being promised.
