Posted: June 25, 2015
												TL;DR6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it, but if you find the chance, then go for itI first saw this game while searching through the deep dark slums of the farthest-back pages of Steam, and was not immediately encouraged to get Door Kickers. It just looked like a bare-bones, top-down shooter with some mediocre ‘tactical’ elements tossed in. I let it be for a while and then came back to it a couple of months later, then decided “what the heck, I’ll buy it”. I had a total blast for the first week, just playing my way through various missions and unlocking various weapons and armor, but after that, I found myself getting really bored. That is, until I discovered the workshop, and let me tell you; that is what makes this game so great.Gameplay wise, Door Kickers really stands out. None of your soldiers are too overpowered (unless you download god armor from the workshop), so you need to use every last drop of tactical knowledge to keep them alive. Nothing is more frustrating then spending twenty minutes working out a plan and then having all of your troops mowed down by some guy with a machine gun hiding behind a bulletproof couch the instance they kick down the first door. To actually complete a mission you need to buckle down and focus, or you are going to end up with only one guy, cowering in the corner, waiting for someone to come and yell a stereotypical phrase at them then blow your final guy’s head off.All in all, Door Kickers won’t blow you away, but if you like tactical games, then you’ll have some fun with it. If you don’t like those games, then this is probably not the game for you. The graphics aren’t great, but the workshop makes up for that by having new stuff constantly made every day for you to try out. So give it a try if you feel like it, but if you don’t like this type of game, then don’t waste your money on it.6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it to a friend, but if you find the chance, then go for itBuy it full price if you have the money on hand, but otherwise buy it on sale.~Mfilms2000You can find more of our reviews on our curator page here:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/technosharkreviews

Posted: June 26, 2015
												A game for tacticians who like their challenges realistic and their options almost infinite.  Every door is a problem to be solved - kick it in? place guys on both sides and open it? breach it? toss flashbangs through? try to go in quiet with silencers? jump in with quick reacting pistol wielders? cautiously have the guy with the shield lead the way? jump in with assault rifles and try to overwhelm with sheer force? Switch out the guns to maximize fire rate or accuracy or stopping power? How many people to assign to the door? Do you leave yourself open to being flanked if you stack people on a door? This game is exactly what I want out of tactical strategy.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												You wanna be a hero? Be a hero for a couple seconds and die! You wanna be tactical? Flashbang and then die. You wanna teamwork? Flashbang, have the shields go first, then send in the assault team, unless is CQC, then send in the breachers, maybe a few more flashbangs, bum rush to the hostages if they're about to be killed with the shields in front of you, as the assault/breachers cover your back, and this time have the breachers shoot down the door, as the assault team (or person if you have a 4 guy squad with 2 shields, a assaulter and a breacher) to take down the enemy. Next (again with the shields in front) find a hallway, and put the shields in front of you, having them slowly advance as you check from door to door. Then, if you don't wanna play the full mission, find a hostage and run for your life! (with the shields behind you). You wanna be a traitor? Well...This is how I would best describe this game. As IGN would put it: "Tactical games at its best."As I would put it, "WHO CARES! FLASHBANG THE CRAP OUTTA THE GUYS AND BUMRUSH THEM! Wait... those are the guys reading my review...?"

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Door kicker is an awesome and addict game. I higly recommend it to everyone. The game is well balanced, easy to play, and very nicely done.There are things however that could be improved. The characters may "improve" in the game but it actually has not much impact. The same applies to weapons, there are lots of weapons which have almost the same statistics, so they don't make much difference. It would be nice to be able to add more customization to weapons, like lamp, laser dot, etc.  So, overall, a great-great game, and i hope there will be a Door Kickers 2 with more improvements.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Excellent, excellent game- the kind of game where you have been playing it and look at the clock and see "Oh, it's bedtime... I will just play one more scenario"- and then three hours later you are like "OMG I gotta work tomorrow!"The music fits perfectly and is awesome (I could just let it play in the background all day), scenarios are quick and replayable.  I have only just begun the content and I feel like I can't get enough of it!  The graphics style and point of view is refreshing.If you don't like a lot of blood I guess that might be a negative point, but I highly recommend this game if you like planning and strategy type games with customization options for your squad members, skill trees, equipment changes... none of these look too overblown but there is just a light enough touch of them to keep it interesting.Waited for this to be on sale but in retrospect, would have paid full price.  Great game so far

Posted: September 13, 2015
												Overall: DecentLikes:- A lot of content- Has procedurally-generated levels- Supports player-created contentDislikes:- Planning out your strategy takes quite a bit of time, even for relatively simple levels.  It's fun but it is also tiresome.- Controlling your characters in real time feels laggy because they move slower than your mouse, and inputs get queued.- I wish you could undo changes to your plan, and save your plans for later use.  I also wish you could edit a section of your route without erasing the subsequent path.- In campaign mode, once you leave a mission, your current state (health, deaths) is saved and you can't retry it from the original state you were in when you first played that mission.  Not a huge deal though.

Posted: July 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Broke my game with mods, sent a very detailed email to Support, they resent me the files to fix the game while also helping me pinpoint the possible mod(s) that broke my game, fixed (and learnt how to fix the problem after an accidental peek of the .xml files). Back to kicking doors and dropping baddies. I do want to point out that some of the bad guys in body armor can take a lot more bullets than you would expect even with high powered rifle rounds that you'd normally expect to go through whatever the bad guys can afford (apparently they can afford AR500 Level 4 armor) so if you're playing without mods, do expect some heavy resistence and lots of baddies with level 4 AR500 if you're using the mission generator and you have enemy resistence setting set to heavy (w/e that one setting is called). Lots of fun, loving the game, great Support, can't wait for DK2 to come out in the near future.Edit: Tasers are fun to use.Edit #2: I can't stop tasering people. I need help.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												This game is fresh to me. I haven't played anything quite like it. You can't do campaign mode right away, you have to play a few single missions and level up first. This is basically to get you warmed up for the campaign missions because campaign there is perma death. Your task force officers rank up too, and your level points get you better gear. Basically a mission operates in 3 phases1. Deploy mode. Select your officers and deploy them onto the mission site in a selected area. 2. Planning mode. This is where you trace out the movement and actions of each officer. There are a variaty of options on how to do this depending on rank and equipment. 3. Execution mode. This is when the mission starts and your men begin to perform your plan, you can go back to planning mode at anytime and redo the planor if you're feeling brave you can do the planning and execution simultaniously. At the end of your mission you are graded by speed, deaths, and overall performance. 3 star ranking gets you more XP which can be used for more lethal officers and tactics. Planning mode gets complcated quick, you can customize it to do so many things like switch weapons, look in certain directions, don't move again until enemies cleared, and there are even wait for order Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, or Delta so a certain officer will wait until you click the order and then continue as plan. This game is quick paced, and a great time killer. I think I will enjoy it for a long time, classic replay value. Overall I give it 8 out of 10 ♥♥♥♥ Pandas

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game really makes you think before you send your teams in. Best blend of tactics and strategy I've ever played in a game. Every mission is different and really makes you put thought into it. So many weapons, armors, and secondaries. You can breach a door with a shotgun and send a squad in with assault rifles with a sniper set outside a window to cover them going in. My favorite part of the game is how you can divvy up your movements into sequences. For instance, once you plan your teams' routes, you can divide their movements to into sections. So. you can have one team sneak in and clear an area silently and cut off an escape route and begin phase "A" where another team will blow their door open for a loud entrance and move in. You can then set phases B thru D for movement after things are clear, certain enemies have been eliminated, etc. It's probably the most satisfying when you're preplanned movements finish a mission without pausing it to readjust.I would suggest maybe a headswivel option for when one of your routes end. This would enable one or more units to watch all around them so they don't get snuck up on.I would also suggest a little more user-friendly map creation.Other than that, this is a must-buy game for those interested in a truly amazing tactical/strategic SWAT game.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												I played this game and enjoyed it.If you liked the old SWAT tactical shooter, here's something you will enjoy. The good thing about this is that there's actual planning invovled - ypou don't just send your men in guns blazing, cause that way most or all of them will go back in bodybags. Here you have to plan ahead and every room you clear matters. One unexpected event will often demand of you to re-think your strategy. This is NOT a game wher eyou plan, then hit "execute" and forget about the whole thing. Far from what it may seem from screenshots or short videos, this is a thinking man's game.Another good part of it is that there's more replayability than meets the eye. The same scenario will vary from one playthrough to the next. You may encounter different number of foes, in diffrent places, with different behaviour, armament and patrol patterns than you seen in your last playthrough of a given scenario. There are a lot of scenarios on tp of it all.There is also an RPG-style mechanic - your SWAT agents will rise in skill after participating in missions, you will also get access to more armor types, weapon and doctrines as you complete more missions. Doctrines act much as passive bonuses in mmorpgs. This works pretty well, although it is primarily a tactical game and the rpg elements are not as deep as in complex mmos.Only two downsides I can think of are two elements from the SWAT games taht I miss here - there's no tear gas and there's little in the way of opponent morale - 99% of foes will fight to the death and not surrender.

Posted: April 21, 2015
												Every now and then, a game comes along and fills a gap in the market that I didn't really know needed to be filled - Door Kickers is one such game. Inspired in no small part by the planning phases of late 1990s Tom Clancy games, Door Kickers is a thought provoking adrenaline rush of anti-terrorism action-puzzles. There's two ways you can play Door Kickers. You can either take advantage of the ability to pause & issue commands in real time, edging your way through a level one command at a time, carefully assessing your options before pushing onwards... Then there's the right way - You plan everything from the get go. One continuous stream of commands that'll see your trooper(s) go from room to room, checking their corners and, hopefully, never leaving themselves open to an ambush. The sense of accomplishment from laying down a perfect plan that requires no tweaking after the mission starts is pretty special, and adds so much challenge to the game that you'll be entertained for hours and hours.Levels vary wildly from simple elimination jobs, to bomb defusal, hostage rescue, and evidence gathering. No two levels are the same, and thanks to the numerous ways to approach each, there's potentially no limit to replayability. Replayability is also helped by a multi-tier challenge system & a pretty strong community modding scene. The in-game custom level generator makes designing & sharing levels with others really simple, and it's fun to see how challenging a level can actually be when designed by someone other than a sensible developer.Character variety is a-plenty as the game has a generous amount of specialized classes & customization, along with veterancy rewards and dedicated fighting styles. Completing campaign levels in the best possible way will require a well rounded squad of multiple talents, but be warned - Death is permanent in campaign modes, and it's possible to lose a talented officer in just one poor move.It's not all great, though. Music & voice acting is less than mediocre, while the graphics are pretty much just fit for purpose. There could also be very slight improvements to mission planning, but the developers have proven their intent to better the game, and it's by no means bad right now - It just could be a little better, that's all.Overall, Door Kickers is a resounding recommendation. A collection of standalone tactical puzzles, campaigns & UGC, all wrapped in an attractive enough package with amazing character customization & challenges galore. If you're in any way  intrigued, then jump in without hesitation.

You gain 'stars' after each successful mission, which you can spend on unlocking new weapons/armors/items that you can assign to any squad member. You could play the built-in missions, generate random ones, or create your own with the editor.So, yes, the game is worth every penny.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												TL;DR6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it, but if you find the chance, then go for itI first saw this game while searching through the deep dark slums of the farthest-back pages of Steam, and was not immediately encouraged to get Door Kickers. It just looked like a bare-bones, top-down shooter with some mediocre ‘tactical’ elements tossed in. I let it be for a while and then came back to it a couple of months later, then decided “what the heck, I’ll buy it”. I had a total blast for the first week, just playing my way through various missions and unlocking various weapons and armor, but after that, I found myself getting really bored. That is, until I discovered the workshop, and let me tell you; that is what makes this game so great.Gameplay wise, Door Kickers really stands out. None of your soldiers are too overpowered (unless you download god armor from the workshop), so you need to use every last drop of tactical knowledge to keep them alive. Nothing is more frustrating then spending twenty minutes working out a plan and then having all of your troops mowed down by some guy with a machine gun hiding behind a bulletproof couch the instance they kick down the first door. To actually complete a mission you need to buckle down and focus, or you are going to end up with only one guy, cowering in the corner, waiting for someone to come and yell a stereotypical phrase at them then blow your final guy’s head off.All in all, Door Kickers won’t blow you away, but if you like tactical games, then you’ll have some fun with it. If you don’t like those games, then this is probably not the game for you. The graphics aren’t great, but the workshop makes up for that by having new stuff constantly made every day for you to try out. So give it a try if you feel like it, but if you don’t like this type of game, then don’t waste your money on it.6.5/10Don’t go out of your way to recommend it to a friend, but if you find the chance, then go for itBuy it full price if you have the money on hand, but otherwise buy it on sale.~Mfilms2000You can find more of our reviews on our curator page here:http://steamcommunity.com/groups/technosharkreviews

												A game for tacticians who like their challenges realistic and their options almost infinite.  Every door is a problem to be solved - kick it in? place guys on both sides and open it? breach it? toss flashbangs through? try to go in quiet with silencers? jump in with quick reacting pistol wielders? cautiously have the guy with the shield lead the way? jump in with assault rifles and try to overwhelm with sheer force? Switch out the guns to maximize fire rate or accuracy or stopping power? How many people to assign to the door? Do you leave yourself open to being flanked if you stack people on a door? This game is exactly what I want out of tactical strategy.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												tactical swat simulator with puzzle elements, and lots of mod and level design support. you essentially plan out a swat raid from a top down, almost blueprint-like map, and then execute the plan to see how it plays out. you can then pasue and adjust as needed, or take direct control of the team members if needed. equip different items and weapons to make your team members effective in different ways. very interesting, with lots of content, and a welcom change of pace.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game really makes you think before you send your teams in. Best blend of tactics and strategy I've ever played in a game. Every mission is different and really makes you put thought into it. So many weapons, armors, and secondaries. You can breach a door with a shotgun and send a squad in with assault rifles with a sniper set outside a window to cover them going in. My favorite part of the game is how you can divvy up your movements into sequences. For instance, once you plan your teams' routes, you can divide their movements to into sections. So. you can have one team sneak in and clear an area silently and cut off an escape route and begin phase "A" where another team will blow their door open for a loud entrance and move in. You can then set phases B thru D for movement after things are clear, certain enemies have been eliminated, etc. It's probably the most satisfying when you're preplanned movements finish a mission without pausing it to readjust.I would suggest maybe a headswivel option for when one of your routes end. This would enable one or more units to watch all around them so they don't get snuck up on.I would also suggest a little more user-friendly map creation.Other than that, this is a must-buy game for those interested in a truly amazing tactical/strategic SWAT game.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												A true tactical game, where tactical means planning and not camping. Making sure that each member of the team knows what they are doing before hand, and executing the plan pefectly is a great feeling.With a good multiplayer, it would redefine the entire tactical genre (hopefully planning returns to other tactical-genred games).

Posted: February 24, 2015
												One of the best tactical games I have ever played. For an overhead 'god' sort of game, this is the best one out there. Combined with levelling up, customising andcontrolling your troopers, the pause/unpause, GO codes and dynamic breaching methods and manouvers this is definently a game worth investing in. Recent updates include lots more challenging maps and campaigns that will keep you hooked for ages. There isn't the same way to complete a mission twice, every time you start a mission, the enemy, hostages and possibly even the bomb change positions, allowing for hours of ever changing fun. Posted: February 24, 2015
												Personally one of the best games in a while. Grinding a perfect game out of this took 44 hours, playing just about every day. And immediately after that, I'm already missing it. It did not start to feel boring or repetitive at any point.There are multiple ways to play this according to your mood. You can carefully (and sometimes a bit tediously) plan out the entire mission, and then relax while watching it success or fail, after which you can adjust it for a rerun. If you don't feel like planning, you can go ad-hoc blasting away in real time, merely pausing in some tight spots.There are some annoyances in the planning, but nothing deal breaking. Addictive game that is fun, quick and easy to start and play a couple of maps - and then a couple more.In the achievements point of view, I liked the fact that achieving everything takes a lot of work, but is eventually accomplishable by anyone. Waiting for added campaign, or better yet, Door Kickers 2 <3 (there is community content for now)

Posted: March 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is buy far the BEST tactical simulators I have played since 1998 with the release of the first rainbow six. Every aspect of the game is, fluid and smoth. Delivering a marvelous feeling of being right there on the ground when the first door charge goes off, all this despite it being a 2D top down view.When I play it in genarall goes like this.1. Get the lay of the land, (Evaluate points of entry, danger zones, decide distrubation of the squad)2. How to go about it, (Plan paths of moment, cover zones, assert pace requierd to meet the time limits)3. Taking a closer look, (Get eyes inside of target building or area, reasses previous planing on the new info)4. Kicking down the door, (Executing previous planing)Step 1-3 takes between 1-5 minutes unless im picky and decides to plan it all down to the tinyest detail,Step 4 goes in about 10 seconds up to a minute. 5. Improvising in 9/10 times the planing can't cover every base so I generaly have to cut in half way or in the first 3 seconds of the execution and re plan from there whit what I have to work with.It is wonderfull to get a perfect run whitout hicups in the plan but its just as thrilling to be able to salvage a "crashed and burned" plan to still be able to execute the rest.There is a lot of games out there that is worth playing only once, Door kickers is NOT among those titles.You can play it over and over and OVER again, succeding and learning failing and learning. Every time it is a brand new game. If you are a fan of tacsim like me you will get hooked.Score 10/10

Posted: November 28, 2014
												Fantastic game. I've always loved the idea of a tactical topdown shooter that's more about planning then spraying bullets, but I've never really liked any of the stealthy games on the market so I can't really compare it to anything I've ever seen and maybe it is very different from anything out there. The only thing that comes to mind is Survivor Squad, but that's about zombies and survival and very unfinished.So all I can say is, they got it right! It's quite easy to control the men, but sometimes quite difficult to find the right tactic to clear a building. At least for somebody that's new to the genre.There's also a little luck involved. Of course you gotta find a tactic that improves your odds, but the some gameplay footage you see in the trailer is a good example of an approach that could get you killed with a little bad luck. Only the bad guys can get a Mac10 which are overpowered.I've played a lot of the Alpha Demo, but this is obviously much better.The controls are still a liiiittle bit odd though. You have to draw the path that your men are going to walk, but a lot of the spaces you go through are very tight and lines will cross. Then when you finish a line it's sometimes hard to tell which one belongs to whom and you finish the wrong line thereby deleting (part of) the path you had just created for the other man. You can give different men different colors, but that doesn't make it easier to select the right one if the game doesn't know which one you're clicking.But it has only been done for a little while and nowadays that means you have to wait an extra 6 months before you can tell if this is the finished product or not.(Don't get me wrong, this game seems pretty much done except for a little tweak here and there. And most of those 'little things' are bugs that I have but most others don't seem to have. So it's nothing like the other unfinished garbage Greenlight brought to Steam.)

Posted: January 5, 2015
												A great Pausable Real Time Squad Based Tactics game! From a top down view, you click and drag your SWAT Team members, drawing a path for them to follow, in which they'll shoot anyone they see, though later on you can tell them to hold their fire. You can have them breach doors through a variety of ways, such as lock picks, kicking, big hammer, small hammer, and bolt cutters for padlocked gates.There's a large selection of guns, ranging from pistols, Shotgun, SMG's, and Rifle. I especially like the P90 POW when raiding houses, and the M4 for more open maps, since the M4's Accuracy and Stopping Power is maxed out, or very close to it. The tradeoff is that they have ]very low maneuverability.I guess Is shouldn't start reviews when I'm dead tired. I'll contine this sometime tomorrow.

												Perfect bite-sized strategy with all the 'one shot gravitas' and faux bravado a good round of Rogue Spear would muster. Part puzzle part strategy with some pseudo RPG elements. Posted: December 30, 2014
												I played this game and enjoyed it.If you liked the old SWAT tactical shooter, here's something you will enjoy. The good thing about this is that there's actual planning invovled - ypou don't just send your men in guns blazing, cause that way most or all of them will go back in bodybags. Here you have to plan ahead and every room you clear matters. One unexpected event will often demand of you to re-think your strategy. This is NOT a game wher eyou plan, then hit "execute" and forget about the whole thing. Far from what it may seem from screenshots or short videos, this is a thinking man's game.Another good part of it is that there's more replayability than meets the eye. The same scenario will vary from one playthrough to the next. You may encounter different number of foes, in diffrent places, with different behaviour, armament and patrol patterns than you seen in your last playthrough of a given scenario. There are a lot of scenarios on tp of it all.There is also an RPG-style mechanic - your SWAT agents will rise in skill after participating in missions, you will also get access to more armor types, weapon and doctrines as you complete more missions. Doctrines act much as passive bonuses in mmorpgs. This works pretty well, although it is primarily a tactical game and the rpg elements are not as deep as in complex mmos.Only two downsides I can think of are two elements from the SWAT games taht I miss here - there's no tear gas and there's little in the way of opponent morale - 99% of foes will fight to the death and not surrender.

												This is awesome. Posted: November 28, 2014
												Fantastic game. I've always loved the idea of a tactical topdown shooter that's more about planning then spraying bullets, but I've never really liked any of the stealthy games on the market so I can't really compare it to anything I've ever seen and maybe it is very different from anything out there. The only thing that comes to mind is Survivor Squad, but that's about zombies and survival and very unfinished.So all I can say is, they got it right! It's quite easy to control the men, but sometimes quite difficult to find the right tactic to clear a building. At least for somebody that's new to the genre.There's also a little luck involved. Of course you gotta find a tactic that improves your odds, but the some gameplay footage you see in the trailer is a good example of an approach that could get you killed with a little bad luck. Only the bad guys can get a Mac10 which are overpowered.I've played a lot of the Alpha Demo, but this is obviously much better.The controls are still a liiiittle bit odd though. You have to draw the path that your men are going to walk, but a lot of the spaces you go through are very tight and lines will cross. Then when you finish a line it's sometimes hard to tell which one belongs to whom and you finish the wrong line thereby deleting (part of) the path you had just created for the other man. You can give different men different colors, but that doesn't make it easier to select the right one if the game doesn't know which one you're clicking.But it has only been done for a little while and nowadays that means you have to wait an extra 6 months before you can tell if this is the finished product or not.(Don't get me wrong, this game seems pretty much done except for a little tweak here and there. And most of those 'little things' are bugs that I have but most others don't seem to have. So it's nothing like the other unfinished garbage Greenlight brought to Steam.)

												I bought this game, because I hate doors.I kept it, because it is a great police tactical game reminding me of the days when I played SWAT.You can do missions in real-time, or pause any time while the action is going, or even turn it into something like a turn based game (where your foe does not respect the rules) and command your team from point to point in your own tempo.You make plans before the action, but you are free to modify it according to the events. Posted: February 24, 2015
												One of the best tactical games I have ever played. For an overhead 'god' sort of game, this is the best one out there. Combined with levelling up, customising andcontrolling your troopers, the pause/unpause, GO codes and dynamic breaching methods and manouvers this is definently a game worth investing in. Recent updates include lots more challenging maps and campaigns that will keep you hooked for ages. There isn't the same way to complete a mission twice, every time you start a mission, the enemy, hostages and possibly even the bomb change positions, allowing for hours of ever changing fun. Definently a game worth buying, worth every cent. 10/10. Hats off to Killhouse Games.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Pros:+ Realistic take on Police CQB action.+ Easy to learn, hard to master.+ Wide selection of gears.+ Simple, yet beautiful and effective 2-D graphics.+ Lots of single missions and some interesting campaigns.+ Ability to record and replay a mission from start to end, even converting it to videos.Cons:- 2-D representation of the action may not appeal to all.- Only a handful of campaigns.- Conversion of replays to video not available for the Mac OS X platform.Bottomline:A perfect game for those of us growing up with the original Rainbow Six and SWAT 3 games, who are wishing for a realistic CQB action.

												I love this game. It had me at "Tango Down!".It has yet to crash on me. Entertains for hours. I have completed the first two campaigns, and working on the third, along with going for all the stars and achievements on the first several screens of maps. I dislike how spy cameras work in planning a breech as you can't have them do it, then switch to another method of breech, or sweep the room then kick the door, which results in pausing, dinking with the plan. I also can't seam to figure out how to add movement waypoints in the middle of an existing way point.  Stealth guys are a little quirky, they need to have the ability to shoot regardless or stay silent, not just a button mash while executing a plan. I like how the dev's kept it real, no crazy sci fi or uber expensive tech gear. That might be a cool expansion a future cop or such. I could also see this being a fun military sim, clearing a city block or such. Overall this game provides plenty of fun for the cost.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												So, you're probably sitting here thinking, "Why don't I just get Breach and Clear?". Here are a few reasons why this game is AWESOME! I got Door Kickers in the autumn sales for £2 (I'm a sucker for a bargain) already I have put 4.1 hours into the game just by playing before and after school before dinner. This game is amazing!The sheer brilliance of the customisation means you can have all kinds of you own "classes" on top of the pre-made ones! For example, I created a line up of solely pointmen with silenced pistols and took out the targets with stealth and cunning rather than brute force. It was cool to think I could do all of these new cool tactics!Now, I'm not one to go through a game and get three stars on every level. I just get bored. But for Door Kickers? The fact that you need stars to customise your squad means I want to 100% the game!Also, another great thing is that the most expensive gun/armour/shield isn't nessecarily the best gun/armour/shield! It's all about how you play the game! You can also upgrade the weapon skills of your squad with pistols, long guns and shotguns! This adds a whole other dynamic to the game as you can upgrade your perks or equipment strategically depending on one other!And of course you can name each member squad! You can be as creative as you like! You could call your "crack-shot-with-a-pistol-guy" anything from "Dead-eye" to "Sh**head" This enables you to be slightly attached to your men and be upset if they are killed in the line of fire. And yes, if your men are killed during a campaign, they will not be replaced by new men until you have won/lost the whole campaign! This makes you think about your choices more carefully during an assault on a building.I would highly recommend this game to ANYONE no matter what games they like/play! I recommend picking it up, especially in a sale! Worth the £14.99 its sold for!

Posted: February 7, 2015
												Door Kickers is an absolutley fantastic top-down tactical shooter, the game is designed to really make you think about the classes you choose and the way you go about things, for example, it's entirely possible for me to have four guys bust through the front door and have them be killed to the last man in 2 seconds flat, on the other hand I can send one guy with some good armor and well placed flashbangs quietly through the back or a window and get a fair way through the stage without even getting hit. There's also a great deal of customization for each character's weapons, armor, and utilities. This allows for a level of mission specific customization that further enhances the experience. The only thing I'd say I didn't like is that at times if caught reloading or lockpicking the interrupt is too long, the character doesn't move at all which usually results in an insta-kill.

Posted: March 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is buy far the BEST tactical simulators I have played since 1998 with the release of the first rainbow six. Every aspect of the game is, fluid and smoth. Delivering a marvelous feeling of being right there on the ground when the first door charge goes off, all this despite it being a 2D top down view.When I play it in genarall goes like this.1. Get the lay of the land, (Evaluate points of entry, danger zones, decide distrubation of the squad)2. How to go about it, (Plan paths of moment, cover zones, assert pace requierd to meet the time limits)3. Taking a closer look, (Get eyes inside of target building or area, reasses previous planing on the new info)4. Kicking down the door, (Executing previous planing)Step 1-3 takes between 1-5 minutes unless im picky and decides to plan it all down to the tinyest detail,Step 4 goes in about 10 seconds up to a minute. 5. Improvising in 9/10 times the planing can't cover every base so I generaly have to cut in half way or in the first 3 seconds of the execution and re plan from there whit what I have to work with.It is wonderfull to get a perfect run whitout hicups in the plan but its just as thrilling to be able to salvage a "crashed and burned" plan to still be able to execute the rest.There is a lot of games out there that is worth playing only once, Door kickers is NOT among those titles.You can play it over and over and OVER again, succeding and learning failing and learning. Every time it is a brand new game. If you are a fan of tacsim like me you will get hooked.Score 10/10

Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a huge fan of the SWAT games I've had my eye on this for some time. After checking out some of the early access reviews I decided to dip my toes in and see what this game had to offer so far - so far, I'm not disappointed. There's a great amount of satisification to watching your carefully planned moves play out and learning from the ones that end in disaster. Posted: November 14, 2014
												For fans of tactical games such as SWAT, Door Kickers is a great find. You command a team of SWAT team members as they raid locations in order to rescue hostages, go in for a drug bust, or otherwise eliminate the bad guys. This is a rare type of game where the tiniest mistake can really cost you, especially in campaign mode. If the default content is not enough (honestly, it should be - there is a lot included here), modding is supported and more levels and weapons may be downloaded from the workshop.

												Door Kickers is an absolutley fantastic top-down tactical shooter, the game is designed to really make you think about the classes you choose and the way you go about things, for example, it's entirely possible for me to have four guys bust through the front door and have them be killed to the last man in 2 seconds flat, on the other hand I can send one guy with some good armor and well placed flashbangs quietly through the back or a window and get a fair way through the stage without even getting hit. There's also a great deal of customization for each character's weapons, armor, and utilities. This allows for a level of mission specific customization that further enhances the experience. The only thing I'd say I didn't like is that at times if caught reloading or lockpicking the interrupt is too long, the character doesn't move at all which usually results in an insta-kill.

												To start this off i dont write many reviews so I hope its ok and ill keep it short and sweet.OMFG Door Kickers is so amazing I just had to review it. So I like strategy games and have only played a few really decent ones (my opinion) Xcom, JA2 and this weird old school flash game called Field Commando or something, Field commando was a 'crappy lil game' that looked like it took 2 seconds to make but the idea of controlling (Very restricted) a military squad was awesome. Door Kickers is what i dreamt Field  Commando would have been if they worked harder. IT IS AMAZING.Pros - Great soundtrack, Keeps up the tension/atmosphere.        - Massive range of difficulty.        - Different types of missions (not just take out the enemy but arresting people and rescuing hostages)        - Graphics are better then Field Commando (you're not a circle haha)        - (To me) Highly replayable, yes I might not sit here for hours playing it but I will deffinatley play it  again and again  when im bored or have time to kill.        - Reasonably priced (although i got 75% off in steam sales paid like 5 bucks US)         - Unlock weapons and armour.        - You can have a squad of like 8 men all taking out different targets at the same time. Feels good to wipe out like 20  enemies in like 2 seconds.Cons - Not many         - Graphics could still be better.         - It will frustrate the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.         - Times dissappears when you have 'just one more crack at the mission'         - Few glitches and my guys died a few times getting shot from someone who they couldnt shoot(i was hiding and they could see and arm, enemies could shoot me but my guy just took it and died.BoldyB - Give it a go. Better value for money then WarZ.....oh wait Infestation surviv......oh you lost interest :(

Posted: June 24, 2016
												I feel that this is a very good game. I like the game concept and pacing of the missions. The missions are interesting but short enough. The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

												Being a die-hard fan of the Rainbow 6 series and SWAT 4, this game does a great job at scratching that tactical itch.  Door Kickers is fantastic in it's ability to blend simple controls with complex gameplay with countless levels in both the game and Steam Workshop to give this game insane replayability. And with a level editor/creator, your map selection is practically limitless.   The game really shines in how it forces the player to be extremely considerate of the layout of the entire level. Posted: September 16, 2016
												Decent game but has many shortcommings. Wait for sale and get it dirt cheap.Level design spans from good to clowncars of baddies - even in home invasion mission there are 1-3 people in every single room of 3 story apartment and you get 4 troppers to clear that! upgrade progression makes no sense in this type of game and is very limiting - it is a big hump at the start of the game, ranking missions based on complete time makes no sense in this type of game (and you need lotsa stars to unlock Stealth class, takes forever!), givig you worthless recruits makes no sense. Too many weapons which do not differ much if at all cluttering the list.The troops will show too much initiative and shoot the first guy they see even if you order them to hook around the doorway and check the far corner, but at the same time they need to be instructed to sidestep around every corner.RNG aspects: your troops will occasionally fail to fire first when a tango shows up even if they are aimed exactly at the corner and static. No ammount of foresight can prevent this on occasions.Did I mention star system? Cannot 3 star all missions as you go along, most of them need equipment and classes you will unlock later, so you might need 1 star many to them go back and try to redo them.I spent hours few years bacl playing Rouge Spear in spectator mode and I expected this to be better.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												A solid turn-based stealth (almost but not quite) action game that reminds me a lot of Monaco in artistic style. Unlike Monaco, however, this game is primarily single-player focused and has a great deal of progression. The game offers over 80 single missions (that you can 3-star if you're a completionist) and also has 3 "campaigns" that unlock after you reach a certain point of in-game progression. In Door-Kickers you can either complete the entire mission in one complex command/turn or go through the mission in real time. While the controls were a bit clunky for real-time play, I found a great balance in the middle of those two play styles, and the option to just brute through a mission can often be useful.The gameplay loop is simple but satifying, but is not explained as thoroughly as I would have liked. The mechanics themselves are similar to frozen synapse but without the pure turn-based nature. CONCLUSION: A nice blend of Monaco and Frozen Synapse. A must-buy on a deep discount; an alright pick-up on full-price.

												This game knows what it is and what it aims to be and accomplishes that very well.  I got this in a bundle that was very cheap, and it blew me away.  At it's full retail price, you'd probably want to look into some gameplay videos first to make sure it's something that you'd enjoy.  The big factor being that it focuses much more on strategy and team prep than rich 3d graphics and hero-esque characters.It can be brutal, but encourages creative thinking and being smart about your choices. Posted: January 17, 2016
												Ignore the time Steam says I have played. I have played about 14 hours of the game overall, most of it done offline while I was traveling.Similar to: Hotline Miami, Rainbow Six 3, SWAT 4Pros-Simple controls that anyone can pick up.-Can be played with one hand.-Game mechanics may be simple, but allow for extremely complex strategies to be played out.-Versetile level editor.-Lots of content in the game, hundreds of standalone missions ranging in difficulty, as well as a handful of campaigns lasting 1 to 2 hours each.-Randomized mission generator.-Scenario Variety-Perfect game to play on a laptop if you have a mouse.-Officer and Squad progression. (new skills, weapons, and classes to unlock)-Pause and play allows you to assess the situation on an action by action basis, giving the player time to think and plan.-Good soundtrack.-Playing with your own music/podcast in the background takes nothing away from the game. Cons-Enviroments can get repetitive. (The level design is varried, I'm talking about the way they look)-Controls don't work well when trying to play in real time.-Some of the bigger levels can get tedious, especially if you are stuck looking for the last enemy, hostage, bomb, etc.-How fast your guys react to getting shot at is random at times.-Steath is underdeveloped.ConclusionThis is the most fun I have had in an RTS ever. This is coming from someone who doesn't really like RTS games. I decided to give this game a shot, mainly because I am a fan of squad based Tactical FPS's (Swat 4 and Arma 3 being my favorites) and this game shared the same concepts. Overall, the game is accessible, but still has the complexity to please seasoned RTS verterans.Recommended to: Players who are looking for an accessible game that has a challenging tactical experience that does not rely on clunky UI or twitch shooting.9 out of 10

												Door Kickers is reminiscent of the tactical SWAT games appropriately named ... SWAT.  Its great to provide that quick tactical fix without drowning the gamer in too much detail.Door kickers bring a considerable graphics update, a story mode, and enough variety in the individual scenarios to keep you from getting bored.  The upgrade system is intuitive and easy to work with.The game experiences some difficulty due in part due to some silly AI from both friendly and enemy NPCs but nothing that can't be overcome with micromanagement (shudder...) but that aside the level of control provided is thorough.  It may appear daunting at first but the tutorial provided at the beginning does a great job of explaining the game mechanics. I don't play this game often but thoroughly enjoy the short bursts when I do.  I got this game during the a steam sale for less than $5 at which price the game is a steal.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game really makes you think before you send your teams in. Best blend of tactics and strategy I've ever played in a game. Every mission is different and really makes you put thought into it. So many weapons, armors, and secondaries. You can breach a door with a shotgun and send a squad in with assault rifles with a sniper set outside a window to cover them going in. My favorite part of the game is how you can divvy up your movements into sequences. For instance, once you plan your teams' routes, you can divide their movements to into sections. So. you can have one team sneak in and clear an area silently and cut off an escape route and begin phase "A" where another team will blow their door open for a loud entrance and move in. You can then set phases B thru D for movement after things are clear, certain enemies have been eliminated, etc. It's probably the most satisfying when you're preplanned movements finish a mission without pausing it to readjust.I would suggest maybe a headswivel option for when one of your routes end. This would enable one or more units to watch all around them so they don't get snuck up on.I would also suggest a little more user-friendly map creation.Other than that, this is a must-buy game for those interested in a truly amazing tactical/strategic SWAT game.

Product received for free
												Broke my game with mods, sent a very detailed email to Support, they resent me the files to fix the game while also helping me pinpoint the possible mod(s) that broke my game, fixed (and learnt how to fix the problem after an accidental peek of the .xml files). Back to kicking doors and dropping baddies. I do want to point out that some of the bad guys in body armor can take a lot more bullets than you would expect even with high powered rifle rounds that you'd normally expect to go through whatever the bad guys can afford (apparently they can afford AR500 Level 4 armor) so if you're playing without mods, do expect some heavy resistence and lots of baddies with level 4 AR500 if you're using the mission generator and you have enemy resistence setting set to heavy (w/e that one setting is called). Posted: September 13, 2015
												Overall: DecentLikes:- A lot of content- Has procedurally-generated levels- Supports player-created contentDislikes:- Planning out your strategy takes quite a bit of time, even for relatively simple levels. Posted: June 24, 2016
												I feel that this is a very good game. I like the game concept and pacing of the missions. The missions are interesting but short enough. The game mechanics are not difficult to learn, but level design and the equipment customization ability allows one to try multiple approaches to complete a mission. With good planning of equipment and paths, the team can complete the actual mission in very short time. There are some things that can be improved. For example, the UI makes it difficult to pick individual team members when they stand very closely together. Path creation UI can also be improved, e.g. to allow easy modification of an early segment without having to redo the rest of the path. The variety of weapons also don't seem to matter so much -- for example, many of rifle choices for assaulter class don't seem to offer distinct advantage compared to e.g. P90 or SAR-18 option. Lastly, it's better if some action options are added, e.g. ability for a team member to look around and clear the room before moving. At the moment, there's only option to look at one direction, confirm that it's clear, move slightly, look at another direction, confirm that it's clear, and so on. Another ability that will come in handy is the ability to synchronize team member to only move after a flashbang (without using go codes), the ability to specify alternate action (e.g. when the door that is supposed to be breached is already opened by someone else), and ability to combine actions on one item during planning (e.g. unlock the door, then throw a flashbang through it).Having said that, those issues are minor, and I still highly recommend this game.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Very enjoyable, softcore-tactical, quick to play timesink. I got it on sale but it is easily worth 10 quid.I liked Frozen Synapse, making detailed plans for goons to follow and succeeding in beating enemies down via superior tactics. Unfortunately, Frozen Synapse is pretty hardcore and I enjoy being able to kick back and watch my men act. Feels like Door Kickers jumps right in, neither being too complicated, nor being too simplistic.There are issues with the game that feel a bit annoying, such as flashbangs not going where they're supposed to go (which I know very well from SWAT4), path editing not being meant for complex planning and some minor UI stuff. However, the game feels polished, solid and well-designed.Gameplay is generally bang boom bang, so don't expect too much in terms of policework. You're gunning down dozens of armed guys and usually within a narrow timeframe.If the trailer had you excited, buy this thing. It's well worth it.

The classes are to make line between the styles and the approach how you are going to deal with enemies. Or you want to be quick or armed to teeth, but last unlocked class Stealth says the game is easiest with these guys who are quiet and fast. Being shield is good with support fire, being assaulter is good for quick killing, breacher is important for opening locked doors and there is nothing good with first class unless you want to play light with pistol.I unlocked all skills before approaching campaign which was supposed to be easy so I just ordered my men to go through the map and in second level they started to die. My levelling up was wasted by deaths, and only one of the experienced crew survived the easy and short campaign so yeah, this game is not easy.

Posted: February 25
												I liked the concept/idea of this game, but haven't played many games of this type/genre.  While you are given a decent amount of control over the characters actions, the simplistic command input lets the gameplay down a bit.Maybe i haven't played long enough to get used to the controls but mis-clicking an earlier part of a path only to wipeout the rest of it seems to be unnecessarily infuriating and should seemily be easily fixed with an undo or autosave (at least when in the start planning phase).  Different coloured paths for each unit and the ability to pin or lock paths to make selection easier on congested halls would also make for smoother and more precise controls.By having a control layout that's compatible with ipad seem to leave me with almost an entire keyboard of useless keys that could be assigned things like undo or pin (or even provide buttons arround the interface screen to toggle).Overall it's not a bad game, the graphics and voices etc. are good and if you map out a few commands at time then play/pause/map/play/pause repeat it works well, but the command entry method hinders my ability to easily effeciently create and execute the ultimate breach plans start to finish.

Posted: February 16
												Haven't played much, but it's just such a satisfying game. When you plan a level just right...oh boy that feels nice (not ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic, but that may change when i've done some of the workshop levels). Alternatively, when you screw up, I find I don't get annoyed, I know how to improve, and I do so. It is fun going back to previous levels with better weaponry an units. Looks good. Runs good. Possibly a little on the expensive side, but there are workshop levels so I imagine the amount of replayability makes up for that. It has the perfect learning curve, in my opinion. Giving you just the right amount of information then letting you fail/succeed. The game in itself is not overtly hard, but it becomes more challenging the better you want to do, for example, if I get 2 stars, that will not be good enough, and I WILL replay it until I get 3 stars (plus the single plan other bonus achievments)

Posted: February 18
												Door Kickers is a top down strategy game where you plan out routes for you swat units to take and clear out the baddies.  There's customization, classess, the every slight presence of RPG elements, and robust and rewarding gameplay.But this is a game I am torn on.  On one hand, it is very well made strategic and tactical experience with LOADS of content to keep you busy if you love it. However, even with its varying levels of difficulty and what should be endless costomization options to suit each level, the gameplay gets stale very fast.  Often times, I found myself asking why there were so many levels because they all blend together into this ubiqitous expereince so quickly.  To be clear, I absolutely love the gameplay and all of the ideas that are brought to the table, but it is needlessly big.  It's like going to see a movie that has a lot of good stuff but it goes on an hour too long.  Now in videogames, that shouldn't be a problem, you just don't play the extra stuff, but here's the rub:  you are paying for it.The $20 price tag is my only issue with the game.  Other than that, it's perfect for a quick play every now and then and delivers all that it should.  If you like strategy games and it's on sale for say, $10 I highly recommend it, but there isn't enough here to justify the 20 dollar tag.

Posted: January 19
												Door Kickers!If you ever wanted to pretend to be a super-strategic commander of your very own SWAT squad... well here you go. This is a draw-your-way kind of weird Rainbow 6 Seige.This game is a strategy puzzle game in the form of a SWAT takedown squad. Sometimes you have to kill everything in the room, sometimes save hostages, sometimes sieze drugs or even disarm a bomb.You have a set-up phase where you need to choose which operators (Pointman, Stealth, Shield, Assault and Breaher) you are going to use. Then you draw out your plan. Ivan goes to the door with Dave, throw in a flashbang and kill everyone in the room.Other maps get really challenging really quickly. Ivan and Dave post up in the back entrance while Steve and Cory set a charge on the front door. When you give the Alpha Signal (you can set up to 4 signals for coordinated use), Steve sets off the door charge while Ivan blasts open the back door with a shotgun. Cory sweeps the room while Steve goes down a hall and elimitates hostiles. Dave clears out the bathroom and bedroom while Ivan flashes and kills everyone in the living room because he has the most armor. Mission complete.The game can be a bit annoying at time. Every mission is random, and every play of that mission is random. So you might have the best and brightest plan but some terrorist from the last run of the plan is in another spot and now there are 4 people in a room that used to have 2. Now three operators are dead and one manages to get through. You play the SAME PLAN again and you get through without a scratch. Nevertheless it is the only thing I do not like about it.7/10 puzzle game

Posted: April 19
												A very fun tactical MOUT-simulator, in the vein of games like breach and clear and frozen synapse. Coolest feature is that you can plan your whole assault out, rather than just one or two steps ahead. You can  also play in real time. Very active developers on the forums and a pretty good modding community.

Posted: April 25
												Super awesome fun that brings back the days of the old 2D SWAT games. Nice interface, well executed game.The biggest gripe, and I'm sure I'm not alone in this, is that it's designed to be a real-time game. You should frequently pause and replan your next few steps. But you might be tempted to try to plan out the entire level from the very start, but alas the game doesn't let you. There are mechanics that require intervetion that will stop your grand plan, so you need to learn to play real-time.The real-time thing is actually fun if you get used to it, but maybe needs a limited amount of saves or something? I hate repetition too much..
